titleStmt.title: THE Tragicall Historie of HAMLET, Prince of Denmarke. By William Shakespeare. Newly imprinted and enlarged to almost as much againe as it was, according to the true and perfect Coppie.

respStmt.resp: Based on version supplied by Gabriel Egan, then regularised, homographed and VARDed by
respStmt.name: Hugh Craig, September, 2017

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by I.R. for N.L. and are to be sold at his shoppe vnder Saint Dunstons Church in Fleetstreet.

editorialDecl.p: The characaters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Character descriptions: Shakespeare, William, The Oxford Shakespeare Hamlet, ed.by G.R. Hibbard (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1998). Hamlet, Prince of Denmark, son of the late King Hamlet and of Gertrude Ophelia, Polonius's daughter Horatio, a poor scholar, friend and confidant of Hamlet Rosencraus, courtier, old school fellow of Hamlet Ghost, of Hamlet's dead father King Claudius, King of Denmark, brother of the late King Hamlet Cornelius Valtemand, Danish councillors, ambassador to Norway Laertes, Polonius's son Polonius, a member of the Danish Privy Council Guyldensterne, courtier, old school fellow of Hamlet Queen Gertrad, Queen of Denmark, widow of the late King Hamlet and now the wife of his brother Claudius Reynaldo, Polonius's servant Osric the Courtier Prologue More than one speaker Barnado, a soldier Francisco, a soldier Marcellus, a soldier Clowne 1, a grave-digger Clowne 2, his crony Gentleman Saylers First Player, leader of the troupe, enacts the role of a king Second Player, enacts the role of a queen Third Player, enacts the role of Lucianus, nephew of the king Doctor/Priest Lord Embassadors Fortinbrasse, Prince of Norway Captain, in Fortinbras's army Messenger Fourth Player

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div1.head: The Tragedie of HAMLET Prince of Denmarke.

stage.l: Enter Barnardo, and Francisco, two Centinels.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Who&H62; is there?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nay answer me. Stand and unfold yourself.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Long live the King,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Barnardo.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You come most carefully upon&H4; your hour,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: It is now struck twelve, get thee to&H4; bed Francisco,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: For&H4; this relief much thanks, it is bitter cold,
And I am sick at heart.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Have you had quiet guard?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Not a mouse stirring.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Well, good night:
If you do meet Horatio and Marcellus,
The rivals of my watch, bid them make haste.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I think I hear them, stand ho, who&H62; is there?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Friends to&H4; this ground.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And Liegemen to&H4; the Dane,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Give you good night.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O, farewell honest soldiers, who&H62; hath relieved you?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Barnardo hath my place; give you good night.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Holla, Barnardo.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Say, what is Horatio there?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: A piece of him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Welcome Horatio, welcome good Marcellus,

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: What, has this thing appeared again tonight?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I have seen nothing.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Horatio says it is but our&Htp; fantasy,
And will&H1; not let belief take hold of him,
Touching this dreaded sight twice seen of us&Htp;,,
Therefore I have entreated him along,
With us&Htp;, to&H9; watch the minutes of this night,
That&H3; if again this apparition come,
He may approve our&Htp; eyes and speak to&H4; it.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Tush, tush, it will&H1; not appear.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Sit down a while,
And let us&Htp;, once again assail your ears,
That&H61; are so&H51; fortified against our&Htp; story,
What we&Htp; have two nights seen.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Well, sit we&Htp; down,
And let us&Htp;, hear Barnardo speak of this.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Last night of all,
When yond same star that&H61; is. westward from the pole,
Had made his course to&H9; illume that&H62; part of heaven
Where now it burns, Marcellus and myself.
The bell then beating one.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Peace, break thee off, look where it comes again.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: In&H4; the same figure like&H4; the King that&H61; is dead.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou art a scholar, speak to&H4; it Horatio.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Looks he not like&H4; the King? mark it Horatio.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Most like&H5;, it harrows me with fear and wonder.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: It would be spoke to&H5;.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Speak to&H4; it Horatio.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: What art thou that&H61; usurpest this time of night,
Together with that&H62; fair and warlike form,
In&H4; which&H61; the Majesty of buried Denmarke
Did sometimes march, by&H4; heaven I charge thee speak.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is offended.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: See it stalks away.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Stay, speak, speak, I charge thee speak.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is gone and will&H1; not answer.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How now Horatio, you tremble and look pale,
Is not this something more than fantasy?
What think you of it?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Before my God I might not this believe,
Without the sensible and true avouch
Of mine own eyes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Is it not like&H4; the King?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: As thou art to&H4; thyself.
Such was the very Armour he had on&H5;,
When he the ambitious Norway combated,
So&H52; frowned he once, when in&H4; an angry parley
He smote the sledded pollax on&H4; the ice.
It is strange.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thus twice before, and jump at this dead hour,
With martial stalk hath he gone by&H4; our&Htp; watch.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: In&H4; what particular thought, to&H9; work I know not,
But in&H4; the gross and scope of mine opinion,
This bodes some strange eruption to&H4; our&Htp; state.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good now sit down, and tell me he that&H61; knows,
Why this same strict and most observant watch
So&H51; nightly toils the subject of the land,
And with such daily cost of brazen Cannon
And foreign mart, for&H4; implements of war,
Why such impress of shipwrights, whose sore task
Does not divide the Sunday from the week,
What might be toward that&H3; this sweaty haste
Doth make the night joint labourer with the day,
Who&H62; is it that&H61; can inform me?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: That&H62; can I.
At least the whisper goes so&H52;; our&Htp; last King,
Whose image even but now appeared to&H4; us&Htp;,,
Was as you know by&H4; Fortinbrasse of Norway,
Thereto pricked on&H5; by&H4; a most emulate pride
Dared to&H4; the combat; in&H4; which&H61; our&Htp; valiant Hamlet,
(For&H3; so&H52; this side of our&Htp; known world esteemed him)
Did slay this Fortinbrasse, who&H61; by&H4; a sealed compact
Well ratified by&H4; law and heraldry
Did forfeit (with his life) all these his lands
Which&H61; he stood seized of, to&H4; the conqueror.
Against the which&H61; a moiety competent
Was gauged by&H4; our&Htp; King, which&H61; had return
To&H4; the inheritance of Fortinbrasse,
Had he been vanquisher; as by&H4; the same comart,
And carriage of the article designed,
His fell to&H4; Hamlet; now Sir, young Fortinbrasse
Of unimproved mettle, hot and full,
Hath in&H4; the skirts of Norway here and there
Sharked up&H5; a list of lawless resolutes
For&H4; food and diet to&H4; some enterprise
That&H61; hath a stomach in&H4; it, which&H61; is no&H2; other
As it doth well appear unto our&Htp; state
But to&H9; recover of us&Htp;, by&H4; strong hand
And terms compulsatory, those foresaid lands
So&H52; by&H4; his father lost; and this I take it,
Is the main motive of our&Htp; preparations
The source of this our&Htp; watch, and the chief head
Of this post haste and Rummage in&H4; the land.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I think it be no&H2; other, but even so&H52;;
Well may it sort that&H3; this portentous figure
Comes armed through our&Htp; watch so&H51; like&H4; the King
That&H61; was and is the question of these wars.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: A moth it is to&H9; trouble the mind's eye:
In&H4; the most high and palmy state of Rome,
A little ere the mightiest Julius fell
The graves stood tenantless, and the sheeted dead
Did squeak and gibber in&H4; the Roman streets
As stars with trains of fire, and dews of blood
Disasters in&H4; the sun; and the moist star,
Upon&H4; whose influence Neptunes Empire stands,
Was sick almost to&H4; doomsday with eclipse.
And even the like&H2; precursor of fear events
As harbingers preceding still the fates
And prologue to&H4; the Omen coming on&H5;
Have heaven and earth together demonstrated
Unto our&Htp; Climatures and countrymen.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: But soft, behold, lo where it comes again
I will&H1; cross it though it blast me: stay illusion,
If thou hast any sound or use of voice,
Speak to&H4; me, if there be any good thing to&H9; be done
That&H61; may to&H4; thee do ease, and grace to&H4; me,
Speak to&H4; me.
If thou art privy to&H4; thy country's fate
Which&H61; happily foreknowing may avoid
O speak:
Or if thou hast uphoarded in&H4; thy life
Extorted treasure in&H4; the womb of earth
For&H4; which&H61; they say your spirits oft walk in&H4; death.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Speak of it, stay and speak, stop it Marcellus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Shall I strike it with my partisan?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Do if it will&H1; not stand.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: It is here.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: It is here.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is gone.
We&Htp; do it wrong being so&H51; Majestical
To&H9; offer it the show of violence,
For&H3; it is as the air, invulnerable,
And our&Htp; vain blows malicious mockery.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: It was about to&H9; speak when the cock crew.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: And then it started like&H4; a guilty thing,
Upon&H4; a fearful summons; I have heard,
The Cock that&H61; is the trumpet to&H4; the morn,
Doth with his lofty and shrill sounding throat
Awake the God of day, and at his warning
Whether in&H4; sea or fire, in&H4; earth or air
The extravagant and erring spirit hies
To&H4; his confine, and of the truth herein
This present object made probation.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It faded on&H4; the crowing of the Cock.
Some say that&H3; ever gainst that&H62; season comes
Wherein our&Htp; Saviour's birth is celebrated
This bird of dawning singeth all night long,
And then they say no&H2; spirit dare stir abroad
The nights are wholesome, then no&H2; planets strike,
No&H2; fairy takes, nor witch hath power to&H9; charm
So&H51; hallowed, and so&H51; gracious is that&H62; time.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: So&H52; have I heard and do in&H4; part believe it,
But look the morn in&H4; russet mantle clad
Walks over the dew of yon high Eastward hill
Break we&Htp; our&Htp; watch up&H5; and by&H4; my advise
Let us&Htp;, impart what we&Htp; have seen tonight
Unto young Hamlet, for&H3; upon&H4; my life
This spirit dumb to&H4; us&Htp;,, will&H1; speak to&H4; him:
Do you consent we&Htp; shall acquaint him with it
As needful in&H4; our&Htp; loves, fitting our&Htp; duty.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let us&Htp; do it I pray, and I this morning know
Where we&Htp; shall find him most convenient.

stage.l: Florish. Enter Claudius, King of Denmarke, Gertrad the Queene,
Counsaile: as Polonius, and his Sonne Laertes,

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Though yet of Hamlet our&Hrp; dear brother's death
The memory be green, and that&H3; it us&Htp;, befitted
To&H9; bear our&Htp; hearts in&H4; grief, and our&Htp; whole Kingdom,
To&H9; be contracted in&H4; one brow of woe
Yet so&H51; far hath discretion fought with nature,
That&H3; we&Htp; with wisest sorrow think on&H4; him
Together with remembrance of ourselves:
Therefore our&Hrp; sometime Sister, now our&Hrp; Queen
The imperial jointress to&H4; this warlike state
Have we&Hrp; as it were with a defeated joy
With an auspicious, and a dropping eye,
With mirth in&H4; funeral, and with dirge in&H4; marriage,
In&H4; equal scale weighing delight and dole
Taken to&H4; wife: nor have we&Hrp; herein barred
Your better wisdoms, which&H61; have freely gone
With this affair along (for&H4; all our&Hrp; thanks)
Now follows that&H3; you know young Fortinbrasse,
Holding a weak supposal of our&Hrp; worth
Or thinking by&H4; our&Hrp; late dear brother's death
Our&Hrp; state to&H9; be disjoined, and out of frame
Colleagued with this dream of his advantage
He hath not failed to&H9; pester us&Hrp;, with message
Importing the surrender of those lands
Lost by&H4; his father, with all bands of law
To&H4; our&Hrp; most valiant brother, so&H51; much for&H4; him:
Now for&H4; ourself, and for&H4; this time of meeting,
Thus much the business is, we&Hrp; have here writ
To&H4; Norway Uncle of young Fortenbrasse
Who&H61; impotent and bedrid scarcely hears
Of this his Nephew's purpose; to&H9; suppress
His further gate herein, in&H4; that&H3; the levies,
The lists, and full proportions are all made
Out of his subject, and we&Hrp; here dispatch
You good Cornelius, and you Valtemand,
For&H4; bearers of this greeting to&H4; old Norway,
Giving to&H4; you no&H2; further personal power
To&H4; business with the King, more than the scope
Of these delated articles allow:
Farewell, and let your haste commend your duty.

sp.speaker: Cor. Vo.
sp.l: In&H4; that&H62;, and all things will&H1; we&Htp; show our&Htp; duty.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: We&Hrp; doubt it nothing, heartily farewell.
And now Laertes what is the news with you?
You told us&Hrp;, of some suit, what is it Laertes?
You cannot speak of reason to&H4; the Dane
And lose your voice; what wouldst thou beg Laertes,?
That&H61; shall not be my offer, not thy asking,
The head is not more native to&H4; the heart
The hand more instrumental to&H4; the mouth
Than is the throne of Denmarke to&H4; thy father,
What wouldst thou have Laertes?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: My dread Lord,
Your leave and favour to&H9; return to&H4; France,
From whence, though willingly I came to&H4; Denmarke,
To&H9; show my duty in&H4; your Coronation;
Yet now I must confess, that&H3; duty done
My thoughts and wishes bend again toward France
And bow them to&H4; your gracious leave and pardon.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Have you your father's leave, what says Polonius?

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Hath my Lord wrong from me my slow leave
By&H4; laboursome petition, and at last
Upon&H4; his will&H0; I sealed my hard consent,
I do beseech you give him leave to&H9; go.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Take thy fair hour Laertes, time be thine
And thy best graces spend it at thy will&H0;:
But now my Cousin Hamlet, and my son.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: A little more than kin, and less than kind.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: How is it that&H3; the clouds still hang on&H4; you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Not so&H51; much my Lord, I am too much in&H4; the son.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Good Hamlet cast thy nighted colour off
And let thine eye look like&H4; a friend on&H4; Denmarke,
Do not forever with thy vailed lids
Seek for&H4; thy noble Father in&H4; the dust,
Thou knowest it is common all that&H61; lives must die,
Passing through nature to&H4; eternity.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I Madam, it is common.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: If it be
Why seems it so&H51; particular with thee.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Seems Madam, nay it is, I know not seems,
It is not alone my inky cloak good mother
Nor customary suites of solemn black
Nor windy suspiration of forced breath
No&H7;, nor the fruitful river in&H4; the eye,
Nor the dejected haviour of the visage
Together with all forms, moods, shapes of grief
That&H61; can devote me truly, these indeed seem,
For&H3; they are actions that&H61; a man might play
But I have that&H62; within which&H61; passes show
These but the trappings and the suites of woe.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: It is sweet and commendable in&H4; your nature Hamlet,
To&H9; give these mourning duties to&H4; your father
But you must know your father lost a father,
That&H62; father lost, lost his, and the survivor bound
In&H4; filial obligation for&H4; some term
To&H9; do obsequious sorrow, but to&H9; persevere
In&H4; obstinate condolement, is a course
Of impious stubbornness, it is unmanly grief,
It shows a will&H0; most incorrect to&H4; heaven
A heart unfortified, or mind impatient
An understanding simple and unschooled
For&H4; what we&Htp; know must be, and is as common
As any the most vulgar thing to&H4; sense,
Why should we&Htp; in&H4; our&Htp; peevish opposition
Take it to&H4; heart, fie, it is a fault to&H4; heaven,
A fault against the dead, a fault to&H4; nature,
To&H4; reason most absurd, whose common theme
Is death of fathers, and who&H61; still hath cried
From the first course, till he that&H61; died today
This must be so&H52;: we&Hrp; pray you throw to&H4; earth
This unprevailing woe, and think of us&Hrp;,
As of a father, for&H3; let the world take note
You are the most immediate to&H4; our&Hrp; throne,
And with no&H2; less nobility of love
Than that&H62; which&H61; dearest father bears his son,
Do I impart toward you for&H4; your intent
In&H4; going back to&H4; school in&H4; Wittenberg,
It is most retrograde to&H4; our&Hrp; desire,
And we&Hrp; beseech you bend you to&H9; remain
Here in&H4; the cheer and comfort of our&Hrp; eye,
Our&Hrp; chiefest courtier, cousin, and our&Hrp; son.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Let not thy mother lose her&H2; prayers Hamlet,
I pray thee stay with us&Htp;,, go not to&H4; Wittenberg.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I shall in&H4; all my best obey you Madam.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Why it is a loving and a fair reply,
Be as ourself in&H4; Denmarke, Madam come,
This gentle and unforced accord of Hamlet
Sits smiling to&H4; my heart, in&H4; grace whereof,
No&H2; jocund health that&H61; Denmarke drinks today,
But the great Cannon to&H4; the clouds shall tell.
And the King's rouse the heaven shall bruit again,
Respeaking earthly thunder; come away.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O that&H3; this too too sallied flesh would melt,
Thaw and resolve itself into a dew,
Or that&H3; the everlasting had not fixed
His cannon gainst seal slaughter, o God, God,
How wary, stale, flat, and unprofitable
Seem to&H4; me all the uses of this world?
Fie on&H4; it, ah fie, it is an unweeded garden
That&H61; grows to&H4; seed, things rank and gross in&H4; nature,
Possess it merely that&H3; it should come thus
But two months dead, nay not so&H51; much, not two,
So&H51; excellent a King, that&H61; was to&H4; this
Hiperion to&H4; a satyr, so&H51; loving to&H4; my mother,
That&H3; he might not beteem the winds of heaven
Visit her&H2; face too roughly, heaven and earth
Must I remember, why she should hang on&H4; him
As if increase of appetite had grown
By&H4; what it fed on&H5;, and yet within a month,
Let me not think on&H4; it; frailty thy name is woman
A little month or ere those shoes were old
With which&H61; she followed my poor father's body
Like&H4; Niobe all tears, why she
O God, a beast that&H61; wants discourse of reason
Would have mourned longer, married with my Uncle,
My father's brother, but no&H2; more like&H4; my father
Than I to&H4; Hercules, within a month,
Ere yet the salt of most unrighteous tears,
Had left the flushing in&H4; her&H2; galled eyes
She married, o most wicked speed; to&H9; post
With such dexterity to&H4; incestuous sheets,
It is not, nor it cannot come to&H4; good,
But break my heart, for&H3; I must hold my tongue.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Hail to&H4; your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I am glad to&H9; see you well; Horatio, or I do forget myself.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: The same my Lord, and your poor servant ever.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Sir my good friend, I will&H1; change that&H62; name with you,
And what make you from Wittenberg Horatio?
Marcellus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My good Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I am very glad to&H9; see you, (good even sir)
But what in&H4; faith make you from Wittenberg?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: A truant disposition good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I would not hear your enemy say so&H52;,
Nor shall you do my ear that&H62; violence
To&H9; make it truster of your own report
Against yourself, I know you are no&H2; truant,
But what is your affair in&H4; Elsonoure?
We&Htp; will&H1; teach you for&H3; to&H9; drink ere you depart.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: My Lord, I came to&H9; see your father's funeral.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I prithee do not mock me fellow studient,
I think it was to&H4; my mother's wedding.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Indeed my Lord it followed hard upon&H5;.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Thrift, thrift, Horatio, the funeral baked meats
Did coldly furnish forth the marriage tables,
Would I had met my dearest foe in&H4; heaven
Or ever I had seen that&H62; day Horatio,
My father, methinks I see my father.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Where my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: In&H4; my mind's eye Horatio.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I saw him once, he was a goodly King.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: He was a man take him for&H4; all in&H4; all
I shall not look upon&H4; his like&H2; again.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: My Lord I think I saw him yesternight.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: saw, who&H62;?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: My Lord the King your father.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: The King my father?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Season your admiration for&H4; a while
With an attent ear till I may deliver
Upon&H4; the witness of these gentlemen
This marvel to&H4; you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: For&H4; God's love let me hear?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Two nights together had these gentlemen
Marcellus, and Barnardo, on&H4; their watch
In&H4; the dead waste and middle of the night
Been thus encountered, a figure like&H4; your father
Armed at point, exactly Cap-a-pe
Appears before them, and with solemn march,
Goes slow and stately by&H4; them; thrice he walked
By&H4; their oppressed and fear surprised eyes
Within his truncheon's length, whilst they distilled
Almost to&H4; jelly, with the act of fear
Stand dumb and speak not to&H4; him; this to&H4; me
In&H4; dreadful secrecy impart they did,
And I with them the third night kept the watch,
Whereas they had delivered both in&H4; time
Form of the thing, each word made true and good,
The Apparition comes: I knew your father,
These hands are not more like&H2;.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: But where was this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My Lord upon&H4; the platform where we&Htp; watch

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Did you not speak to&H4; it?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: My Lord I did,
But answer made it none, yet once methought
It lifted up&H5; it head, and did address
Itself to&H4; motion like&H3; as it would speak:
But even then the morning Cock crewe loud,
And at the sound it shrunk in&H4; haste away
And vanished from our&Htp; sight.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It is very strange.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: As I do live my honoured Lord it is true
And we&Htp; did think it writ down in&H4; our&Htp; duty
To&H9; let you know of it.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Indeed Sirs but this troubles me,
Hold you the watch tonight?

sp.speaker: Bar. Hora. Mar.
sp.l: We&Htp; do my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Armed say you?

sp.speaker: Bar. Hora. Mar.
sp.l: Armed my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: From top to&H4; toe?

sp.speaker: Bar. Hora. Mar.
sp.l: My Lord from head to&H4; foot.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Then saw you not his face.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: O yes my Lord, he wore his beaver up&H5;.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What looked he frowningly?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: A countenance more in&H4; sorrow than in&H4; anger.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Pale, or red?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Nay very pale.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: And fixed his eyes upon&H4; you?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Most constantly.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I would I had been there.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: It would have much amazed you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Very like&H5;, stayed it long?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: While one with moderate haste might tell a hundredth.

sp.speaker: Bar. Mar.
sp.l: Longer, longer.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Not when I saw it.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: His beard was grizzled, no&H5;.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: It was as I have seen it in&H4; his life
A sable silvered.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I will&H1; watch tonight
Perchance it will&H1; walk again.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I warrant it will&H1;.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: If it assume my noble father's person,
I will&H1; speak to&H4; it though hell itself should gape
And bid me hold my peace; I pray you all
If you have hitherto concealed this sight
Let it be tenable in&H4; your silence still,
And what somever else shall hap tonight,
Give it an understanding but no&H2; tongue,
I will&H1; requite your loves, so&H3; fare you well:
Upon&H4; the platform twixt eleven and twelve
I will&H1; visit you.

sp.speaker: Bar. Hora. Mar.
sp.l: Our&Htp; duty to&H4; your honour.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Your loves, as mine to&H4; you, farewell.
My father's spirit (in&H4; arms) all is not well,
I doubt some foul play, would the night were come,
Till then sit still my soul, fond deeds will&H1; rise
Though all the earth overwhelm them to&H4; men's eyes.

stage.l: Enter Laertes, and Ophelia his Sister.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: My necessaries are enbarked, farewell,
And sister, as the winds give benefit
And convey, in&H4; assistant do not sleep
But let me here from you.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: Do you doubt that&H62;?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: For&H4; Hamlet, and the trifling of his favour,
Hold it a fashion, and a toy in&H4; blood
A Violet in&H4; the youth of primy nature,
Forward, not permanent, sweet, not lasting,
The perfume and suppliance of a minute
No&H2; more.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: No&H2; more but so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Think it no&H2; more.
For&H3; nature crescent does not grow alone
In&H4; thews and bulks, but as this temple waxes
The inward service of the mind and soul
Grows wide withal, perhaps he loves you now,
And now no&H2; soil nor cautel doth besmirch
The vertue of his will&H0;, but you must fear,
His greatness weighed, his will&H0; is not his own,
He may not as unvalued persons do,
Carve for&H4; himself, for&H3; on&H4; his choice depends
The safety and health of this whole state,
And therefore must his choice be circumscribed
Unto the voice and yielding of that&H62; body
Whereof he is the head, then if he says he loves you,
It fits your wisdom so&H51; far to&H9; believe it
As he in&H4; his particular act and place
May give his saying deed, which&H61; is no&H2; further
Than the main voice of Denmarke goes withal.
Then weigh what loss your honour may sustain
If with too credent ear you list his songs
Or lose your heart, or your chaste treasure open
To&H4; his unmastered importunity.
Fear it Ophelia, fear it my dear sister,
And keep you in&H4; the rear of your affection
Out of the shot and danger of desire,
"The chariest maid is prodigal enough
If she unmask her&H2; beauty to&H4; the Moon
"Vertue itself scapes not calumnious strokes
"The canker galls the infants of the spring
Too oft before their buttons be disclosed,
And in&H4; the morn and liquid dew of youth
Contagious blastments are most imminent,
Be wary then, best safety lies in&H4; fear,
Youth to&H4; itself rebels, though non else near.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: I shall the effect of this good lesson keep
As watchman to&H4; my heart, but good my brother
Do not as some ungracious pastors do,
Show me the steep and thorny way to&H4; heaven
Whiles a puffed, and reckless libertine
Himself the primrose path of dalliance treads.
And reeks not his own reed.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: O fear me not,
I stay too long, but here my father comes
A double blessing, is a double grace,
Occasion smiles upon&H4; a second leave.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Yet here Laertes? aboard, aboard for&H4; shame,
The wind sits in&H4; the shoulder of your sail,
And you are stayed for&H5;, there my blessing with thee,
And these few precepts in&H4; thy memory
Look thou character, give thy thoughts no&H2; tongue,
Nor any unproportioned thought his act,
Be thou familiar, but by&H4; no&H2; means vulgar,
Those friends thou hast, and their adoption tried,
Grapple them unto thy soul with hoops of steel,
But do not dull thy palm with entertainment
Of each new hatched unfledged courage, beware
Of entrance to&H4; a quarrel, but being in&H5;,
Bear it that&H3; the opposed may beware of thee,
Give every man thy ear, but few thy voice,
Take each man's censure, but reserve thy judgment,
Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy,
But not expressed in&H4; fancy; rich not gaudy,
For&H3; the apparel oft proclaims the man
And they in&H4; France of the best rank and station,
Or of a most select and generous, chief in&H4; that&H62;:
Neither a borrower nor a lender be,
For&H3; love oft looses both itself, and friend,
And borrowing dulleth edge of husbandry;
This above all, to&H4; thine own self be true
And it must follow as the night the day
Thou canst not then be false to&H4; any man:
Farewell, my blessing season this in&H4; thee.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Most humbly do I take my leave my Lord.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: The time invests you go, your servants tend.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Farewell Ophelia, and remember well
What I have said to&H4; you.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: It is in&H4; my memory locked
And you yourself shall keep the key of it.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: What is it Ophelia he hath said to&H4; you?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: So&H3; please you, something touching the Lord Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Marry well bethought
It is told me he hath very oft of late
Given private time to&H4; you, and you yourself
Have of your audience been most free and bounteous,
If it be so&H52;, as so&H52; it is put on&H4; me,
And that&H62; in&H4; way of caution, I must tell you,
You do not understand yourself so&H51; clearly
As it behooves my daughter, and your honour,
What is between you give me up&H5; the truth,

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: He hath my Lord of late made many tenders
Of his affection to&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Affection, puh, you speak like&H4; a green girl
Unsifted in&H4; such perilous circumstance,
Do you believe his tenders as you call them?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: I do not know my Lord what I should think.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Marry I will&H1; teach you, think yourself a baby
That&H3; you have taken these tenders for&H4; true pay
Which&H61; are not sterling, tender yourself more dearly
Or (not to&H9; crack the wind of the poor phrase
Wrong it thus) you will&H1;, tender me a fool.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: My Lord he hath importuned me with love
In&H4; honourable fashion.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Aye, fashion you may call it, go to&H5;, go to&H5;.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: And hath given countenance to&H4; his speech
My Lord, with almost all the holy vows of heaven.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Aye, springs to&H9; catch wood-cocks, I do know
When the blood burns, how prodigal the soul
Lends the tongue vows, these blazes daughter
Giving more light than heat, extinct in&H4; both
Even in&H4; their promise, as it is a-making
You must not take for&H4; fire, from this time
Be something scanter of your maiden presence
Set your entreatments at a higher rate
Than a command to&H9; parley; for&H4; Lord Hamlet,
Believe so&H51; much in&H4; him that&H3; he is young,
And with a larger tether may he walk
Than may be given you: in&H4; few Ophelia,
Do not believe his vows, for&H3; they are brokers
Not of that&H62; die which&H61; their investments show
But mere implorators of unholy suites
Breathing like&H4; sanctified and pious bonds
The better to&H9; beguide: this is for&H4; all,
I would not in&H4; plain terms from this time forth
Have you so&H51; slander any moment leisure
As to&H9; give words or talk with the Lord Hamlet,
Look to&H4; it I charge you, come your ways.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: I shall obey my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: The air bites shrewdly, it is very cold.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: It is nipping, and an eager air.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What hour now?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I think it lacks of twelve.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No&H7;, it is struck.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Indeed; I heard it not, it then draws near the season,
Wherein the spirit held his wont to&H9; walk

stage.l: A florish of trumpets and 2. peeces goes of.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: What does this mean my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: The King doth wake tonight and takes his rouse.
Keeps wassail and the swaggering up-spring reels:
And as he drains his drafts of Rhenish down,
The kettle drum, and trumpet, thus bray out
The triumph of his pledge.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Is it a custom?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Aye marry is it,
But to&H4; my mind, though I am native here
And to&H4; the manner borne, it is a custom
More honoured in&H4; the breach, than the observance.
This heavy headed reveal east and west
Makes us&Htp;, traduced, and taxed of other nations,
They clip us&Htp;, drunkards, and with Swinish phrase
Soil our&Htp; addition, and indeed it takes
From our&Htp; achievements, though performed at height
The pith and marrow of our&Htp; attribute,
So&H51; oft it chances in&H4; particular men,
That&H3; for&H4; some vicious mole of nature in&H4; them
As in&H4; their birth wherein they are not guilty,
(Since nature cannot choose his origin)
By&H4; their overgrowth of some complexion
Oft breaking down the pales and forts of reason,
Or by&H4; some habit, that&H61; too much ore-leavens
The form of plausive manners, that&H3; these men
Carrying I say the stamp of one defect
Being Nature's livery, or Fortune's star,
His virtues else be they as pure as grace,
As infinite as man may undergo,
Shall in&H4; the general censure take corruption
From that&H62; particular fault: the dram of eale
Doth all the noble substance of a doubt
To&H4; his own scandal.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Look my Lord it comes.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Angels and Ministers of grace defend us&Htp;,:
Be thou a spirit of health, or goblin
damned,
Bring with thee airs from heaven, or blasts from hell,
Be thy intents wicked, or charitable,
Thou comest in&H4; such a questionable shape,
That&H3; I will&H1; speak to&H4; thee, I will&H1; call thee Hamlet,
King, father, royal Dane, o answer me,
Let me not burst in&H4; ignorance, but tell
Why thy canonised bones hearsed in&H4; death
Have burst their cerements? why the Sepulchre,
Wherein we&Htp; saw thee quietly interred
Hath oped his ponderous and marble jaws,
To&H9; cast thee up&H5; again? what may this mean
That&H3; thou dead corse, again in&H4; complete steel
Revisits thus the glimpses of the Moon,
Making night hideous, and we&Htp; fools of nature
So&H51; horridly to&H9; shake our&Htp; disposition
With thoughts beyond the reaches of our&Htp; souls,
Say why is this, wherefore, what should we&Htp; do?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: It beckons you to&H9; go away with it
As if it some impartment did desire
To&H4; you alone.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Look with what courteous action
It waves you to&H4; a more removed ground,
But do not go with it.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: No&H7;, by&H4; no&H2; means.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It will&H1; not speak, then I will&H1; follow it.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Do not my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why what should be the fear,
I do not set my life at a pin's fee,
And for&H4; my soul, what can it do to&H4; that&H62;
Being a thing immortal as itself;
It waves me forth again, I will&H1; follow it.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: What if it tempt you toward the flood my Lord,
Or to&H4; the dreadful summit of the cliff
That&H61; beetles over his base into the sea,
And there assume some other horrible form
Which&H61; might deprive your sovereignty of reason,
And draw you into madness, think of it,
The very place puts toys of desperation
Without more motive, into every brain
That&H61; looks so&H51; many fathoms to&H4; the sea
And hears it roar beneath.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It waves me still,
Go on&H5;, I will&H1; follow thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You shall not go my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Hold of your hands.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Be ruled, you shall not go.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: My fate cries out
And makes each petty artery in&H4; this body
As hardy as the Nemeon Lion's nerve;
Still am I called, unhand me Gentlemen
By&H4; heaven I will&H1; make a ghost of him that&H61; lets me,
I say away, go on&H5;, I will&H1; follow thee.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: He waxes desperate with imagine.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let us&Htp; follow, it is not fit thus to&H9; obey him.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Have after, to&H4; what issue will&H1; this come?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Something is rotten in&H4; the state of Denmarke.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Heaven will&H1; direct it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay let us&Htp; follow him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Whither wilt thou lead me, speak, I will&H1; go no&H2; further.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Mark me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I will&H1;.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: My hour is almost come
When I to&H4; sulphurous and tormenting flames
Must render up&H5; myself.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Alas poor Ghost.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Pity me not, but lend thy serious hearing
To&H4; what I shall unfold.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Speak, I am bound to&H9; hear.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: So&H52; art thou to&H9; revenge, when thou shalt hear.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: I am thy father's spirit,
Doomed for&H4; a certain term to&H9; walk the night,
And for&H4; the day confined to&H9; fast in&H4; fires,
Till the foul crimes done in&H4; my days of nature
Are burnt and purged away: but that&H3; I am forbid
To&H9; tell the secrets of my prison house,
I could a tale unfold whose lightest word
Would harrow up&H5; thy soul, freeze thy young blood,
Make thy two eyes like&H4; stars start from their spheres,
Thy knotted and combined locks to&H9; part,
And each particular hair to&H9; stand on&H4; end,
Like&H4; quills upon&H4; the fearful Porpentine,
But this eternal blazon must not be
To&H4; ears of flesh and blood, list, list, o list:
If thou didst ever thy dear father love.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O God.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Revenge his foul, and most unnatural murther.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Murther.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Murther most foul, as in&H4; the best it is,
But this most foul, strange and unnatural.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Haste me to&H9; know it,, that&H3; I with wings as swift
As meditation, or the thoughts of love
May sweep to&H4; my revenge.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: I find thee apt,
And duller shouldst thou be than the fat weed
That&H61; roots itself in&H4; ease on&H4; Lethe wharf,
Wouldst thou not stir in&H4; this; now Hamlet hear,
It is given out, that&H3; sleeping in&H4; my Orchard,
A Serpent stung me, so&H52; the whole ear of Denmarke
Is by&H4; a forged process of my death
Rankly abused: but know thou noble Youth,
The Serpent that&H61; did sting thy father's life
Now wears his Crown.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O my prophetic soul! my Uncle?

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Aye that&H62; incestuous, that&H62; adulterate beast,
With witchcraft of his wits, with traitorous gifts,
O wicked wit, and gifts that&H61; have the power
So&H51; to&H9; seduce; won to&H4; his shameful lust
The will&H0; of my most seeming virtuous Queen;
O Hamlet, what falling off was there
From me whose love was of that&H62; dignity
That&H3; it went hand in&H4; hand, even with the vow
I made to&H4; her&H6; in&H4; marriage, and to&H9; decline
Upon&H4; a wretch whose natural gifts were poor,
To&H4; those of mine; but vertue as it never will&H1; be moved,
Though lewdness court it in&H4; a shape of heaven
So&H52; but though to&H4; a radiant Angle linked,
Will&H1; sort itself in&H4; a celestial bed
And prey on&H4; garbage.
But soft, methinks I scent the morning air,
Brief let me be; sleeping within my Orchard,
My custom always of the afternoon,
Upon&H4; my secure hour, thy Uncle stole
With juice of cursed Hebona in&H4; a vial,
And in&H4; the porches of my ears did pour
The leprous distilment, whose effect
Holds such an enmity with blood of man,
That&H3; swift as quicksilver it courses through
The natural gates and allies of the body,
And with a sudden vigour it doth possess
And cured like&H4; eager droppings into milk,
The thin and wholesome blood; so&H52; did it mine,
And a most instant tetter barks about
Most lazar-like with vile and loathsome crust
All my smooth body.
Thus was I sleeping by&H4; a brother's hand,
Of life, of Crown, of Queen at once dispatched,
Cut off even in&H4; the blossoms of my sin,
Unouseled, disappointed, unaneled,
No&H2; reckoning made, but sent to&H4; my account
With all my imperfections on&H4; my head,
O horrible, o horrible, most horrible.
If thou hast nature in&H4; thee bear it not,
Let not the royal bed of Denmarke be
A couch for&H4; luxury and damned incest.
But howsomever thou pursues this act,
Taint not thy mind, nor let thy soul contrive
Against thy mother aught, leave her&H6; to&H4; heaven,
And to&H4; those thorns that&H61; in&H4; her&H2; bosom lodge
To&H9; prick and sting her&H6;, fare thee well at once,
The Glowworm shows the matin to&H9; be near
And gins to&H9; pale his uneffectual fire,
Adieu, adieu, adieu, remember me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O all you host of heaven, o earth, what else,
And shall I couple hell, o fie, hold, hold my heart,
And you my sinews, grow not instant old,
But bear me swiftly up&H5;; remember thee,
Aye thou poor Ghost whiles memory holds a seat
In&H4; this distracted globe, remember thee,
Yea, from the table of my memory
I will&H1; wipe away all trivial fond records,
All saws of books, all forms, all pressures past
That&H61; youth and observation copied there,
And thy commandment all alone shall live,
Within the book and volume of my brain
Unmixed with baser matter, yes by&H4; heaven,
O most pernicious woman.
O villain, villain, smiling damned villain,
My tables, meet it is I set it down
That&H3; one may smile, and smile, and be a villain,
At least I am sure it may be so&H52; in&H4; Denmarke.
So&H3; Uncle, there you are, now to&H4; my word,
It is adieu, adieu, remember me.
I have sworn it.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Lord Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Heavens secure him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: So&H52; be it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Illo, ho, ho, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Hillo, ho, ho, boy come, and come.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How is it my noble Lord?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: What news my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O, wonderful.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Good my Lord tell it.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No&H7;, you will&H1; reveal it.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Not I my Lord by&H4; heaven.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nor I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How say you then, would heart of man once think it,
But you will&H1; be secret.

sp.speaker: Hora. Mar.
sp.l: I by&H4; heaven.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: There is never a villain,
Dwelling in&H4; all Denmarke
But he is an arrant knave.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: There needs no&H2; Ghost my Lord, come from the grave
To&H9; tell us&Htp;, this.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why right, you are in&H4; the right,
And so&H3; without more circumstance at all
I hold it fit that&H3; we&Htp; shake hands and part,
You, as your business and desire shall point you,
For&H3; every man hath business and desire
Such as it is, and for&H4; my own poor part
I will&H1; go pray.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: These are but wild and whirling words my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I am sorry they offend you heartily,
Yes faith heartily.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: There is no&H2; offence my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Yes by&H4; Saint Patrick but there is Horatio,
And much offence too, touching this vision here,
It is an honest Ghost that&H62; let me tell you,
For&H4; your desire to&H9; know what is between us&Htp;,
Overmaster it as you may, and now good friends,
As you are friends, scholars, and soldiers,
Give me one poor request.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: What is it my Lord, we&Htp; will&H1;.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Never make known what you have seen tonight.

sp.speaker: Hora. Mar.
sp.l: My Lord we&Htp; will&H1; not.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay but swear it.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: In&H4; faith my Lord not I.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nor I my Lord in&H4; faith.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Upon&H4; my sword.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We&Htp; have sworn my Lord already.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Indeed upon&H4; my sword, indeed.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Swear.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Ha, ha, boy, sayst thou so&H52;, art thou there truepenny?
Come on&H5;, you hear this fellow in&H4; the Cellarage,
Consent to&H9; swear.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Propose the oath my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Never to&H9; speak of this that&H61; you have seen
Swear by&H4; my sword.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Swear.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Hic, et vbique, then we&Htp; will&H1; shift our&Htp; ground:
Come hither Gentlemen
And lay your hands again upon&H4; my sword,
Swear by&H4; my sword
Never to&H9; speak of this that&H61; you have heard.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Swear by&H4; his sword.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Well said old Mole, canst work in&H4; the earth so&H51; fast,
A worthy Pioneer, once more remove good friends.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: O day and night, but this is wondrous strange.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: And therefore as a stranger give it welcome,
There are more things in&H4; heaven and earth Horatio
Than are dreamed of in&H4; your philosophy, but come
Here as before, never so&H3; help you mercy,
(How strange or odd soever I bear myself,
As I perchance hereafter shall think meet,
To&H9; put an Antic disposition on&H5;
That&H3; you at such times seeing me, never shall
With arms encumbered thus, or this head shake,
Or by&H4; pronouncing of some doubtful phrase,
As well, well, we&Htp; know, or we&Htp; could and if we&Htp; would,
Or if we&Htp; list to&H9; speak, or there be and if they might,
Or such ambiguous giving out, to&H9; note)
That&H3; you know aught of me, this do swear,
So&H3; grace and mercy at your most need help you.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Swear.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Rest, rest, perturbed spirit: so&H3; Gentlemen,
Withal my love I do commend me to&H4; you,
And what so&H51; poor a man as Hamlet is,
May do to&H9; express his love and friending to&H4; you
God willing shall not lack, let us&Htp;, go in&H4; together,
And still your fingers on&H4; your lips I pray,
The time is out of joint, o cursed spite
That&H3; ever I was borne to&H9; set it right.
Nay come, let us&Htp; go together.

stage.l: Enter old Polonius, with his man or two.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Give him this money, and these notes Reynaldo.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: I will&H1; my Lord.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: You shall do marvellous wisely good Reynaldo,
Before you visit him, to&H9; make inquire
Of his behaviour.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: My Lord, I did intend it.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Marry well said, very well said; look you sir,
Enquire me first what Danskers are in&H4; Parris,
And how, and who&H61;, what means, and where they keep,
What company, at what expense, and finding
By&H4; this encompassment, and drift of question
That&H3; they do know my son, come you more nearer
Than your particular demands will&H1; touch it,
Take you as it were some distant knowledge of him,
As thus, I know his father, and his friends,
And in&H4; part him, do you mark this Reynaldo?

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Aye, very well my Lord.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: And in&H4; part him, but you may say, not well,
But if it be he I mean, he is very wild,
Addicted so&H52; and so&H52;, and there put on&H4; him
What forgeries you please, marry none so&H51; rank
As may dishonour him, take heed of that&H62;,
But sir, such wanton, wild, and usual slips,
As are companions noted and most known
To&H4; youth and liberty.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: As gaming my Lord.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Aye, or drinking, fencing, swearing,
Quarrelling, drabbing, you may go so&H51; far.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: My Lord, that&H62; would dishonour him.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Faith as you may season it in&H4; the charge.
You must not put another scandal on&H4; him,
That&H3; he is open to&H4; incontinency,
That&H62; is not my meaning, but breath his faults so&H51; quaintly
That&H3; they may seem the taints of liberty,
The flash and outbreak of a fiery mind,
A savageness in&H4; unreclaimed blood,
Of general assault.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: But my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Wherefore should you do this?

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: I my Lord, I would know that&H62;.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Marry sir, here is my drift,
And I believe it is a fetch of wit,
You laying these slight sallies on&H4; my son
As it were a thing a little soiled with working,
Mark you, your party in&H4; converse, him you would sound
Having ever seen in&H4; the prenominate crimes
The youth you breath of guilty, be assured
He closes with you in&H4; this consequence,
Good sir, (or so&H3;,) or friend, or gentleman,
According to&H4; the phrase, or the addition
Of man and country.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Very good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p:
And then sir does he this, he does, what was I about to&H9; say?
By&H4; the mass I was about to&H9; say something,
Where did I leave?

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: At closes in&H4; the consequence.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: At closes in&H4; the consequence, aye marry,
He closes thus, I know the gentleman,
I saw him yesterday, or the other day,
Or then, or then, with such or such, and as you say,
There was a gaming there, or took in&H4; his rouse,
There falling out at Tennis, or perchance
I saw him enter such a house of sale,
Videlicet, a brothel, or so&H52; forth, see you now,
Your bait of falsehood take this carp of truth,
And thus do we&Htp; of wisdom, and of reach,
With windlasses, and with assays of bias,
By&H4; indirections find directions out,
So&H52; by&H4; my former lecture and advise
Shall you my son; you have me, have you not?

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: My Lord, I have.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: God buy ye, far ye well.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Observe his inclination in&H4; yourself.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: I shall my Lord.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: And let him ply his music.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: Well my Lord.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Farewell. How now Ophelia, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: O my Lord, my Lord, I have been so&H51; affrighted,

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: With what in&H4; the name of God?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: My Lord, as I was sowing in&H4; my closet,
Lord Hamlet with his doublet all unbraced,
No&H2; hat upon&H4; his head, his stockings fouled,
Ungartered, and down gyved to&H4; his ankle,
Pale as his shirt, his knees knocking each other,
And with a look so&H51; piteous in&H4; purport
As if he had been loosed out of hell
To&H9; speak of horrors, he comes before me.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Mad for&H4; thy love?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: My lord I do not know,
But truly I do fear it.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: What said he?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: He took me by&H4; the wrist, and held me hard,
Then goes he to&H4; the length of all his arm,
And with his other hand thus over his brow,
He falls to&H4; such perusal of my face
As he would draw it, long stayed he so&H52;,
At last, a little shaking of mine arm,
And thrice his head thus waving up&H5; and down,
He raised a sigh so&H51; piteous and profound
As it did seem to&H9; shatter all his bulk,
And end his being; that&H62; done, he lets me go,
And with his head over his shoulder turned
He seemed to&H9; find his way without his eyes,
For&H3; out a-doors he went without their helps,
And to&H4; the last bended their light on&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Come, go with me, I will&H1; go seek the King,
This is the very ecstasy of love,
Whose violent property fordoes itself,
And leads the will&H0; to&H4; desperate undertakings
As oft as any passions under heaven
That&H61; does afflict our&Htp; natures: I am sorry,
What, have you given him any hard words of late?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: No&H7; my good Lord, but as you did command
I did repel his letters, and denied
His access to&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: That&H62; hath made him mad.
I am sorry, that&H3; with better heed and judgment
I had not coated him, I feared he did but trifle
And meant to&H9; wrack thee, but beshrew my Jealousy:
By&H4; heaven it is as proper to&H4; our&Htp; age
To&H9; cast beyond ourselves in&H4; our&Htp; opinions,
As it is common for&H4; the younger sort
To&H9; lack discretion; come, go we&Htp; to&H4; the King,
This must be known, which&H61; being kept close, might move
More grief to&H9; hide, than hate to&H9; utter love,
Come.

stage.l: Florish. Enter King and Queene, Rosencraus and

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Welcome dear Rosencraus, and Guyldensterne,
Moreover, that&H3; we&Hrp; much did long to&H9; see you,
The need we&Hrp; have to&H9; use you did provoke
Our&Hrp; hasty sending, something have you heard
Of Hamlets transformation, so&H52; call it,
Sith nor the exterior, nor the inward man
Resembles that&H62; it was, what it should be,
More than his father's death, that&H61; thus hath put him
So&H51; much from the understanding of himself
I cannot dream of: I entreat you both
That&H3; being of so&H51; young days brought up&H5; with him,
And sith so&H51; neighboured to&H4; his youth and behaviour,
That&H3; you vouchsafe your rest here in&H4; our&Htp; Court
Some little time, so&H52; by&H4; your companies
To&H9; draw him on&H5; to&H4; pleasures, and to&H9; gather
So&H51; much as from occasion you may glean,
Whether aught to&H4; us&Hrp;, unknown afflicts him thus,
That&H61; opened lies within our&Hrp; remedy.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Good gentlemen, he hath much talked of you,
And sure I am, two men there is not living
To&H4; whom he more adheres, if it will&H1; please you
To&H9; show us&Htp;, so&H51; much gentry and good will&H0;,
As to&H9; expend your time with us&Htp;, a while,
For&H4; the supply and profit of our&Htp; hope,
Your visitation shall receive such thanks
As fits a King's remembrance.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Both your Majesties
Might by&H4; the sovereign power you have of us&Htp;,
Put your dread pleasures more into command
Than to&H4; entreaty.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.l: But we&Htp; both obey.
And here give up&H5; ourselves in&H4; the full bent,
To&H9; lay our&Htp; service freely at your feet
To&H9; be commanded.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Thanks Rosencraus, and gentle Guyldensterne.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Thanks Guyldensterne, and gentle Rosencraus.
And I beseech you instantly to&H9; visit
My too much changed son, go some of you
And bring these gentlemen where Hamlet is.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.l: Heavens make our&Htp; presence and our&Htp; practices
Pleasant and helpful to&H4; him.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Aye Amen.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: The ambassadors from Norway my good Lord,
Are joyfully returned.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Thou still hast been the father of good news.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Have I my Lord? I assure my good Liege
I hold my duty as I hold my soul,
Both to&H4; my God, and to&H4; my gracious King;
And I do think, or else this brain of mine
Hunts not the trail of policy so&H51; sure
As it hath used to&H9; do, that&H3; I have found
The very cause of Hamlets lunacy.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: O speak of that&H62;, that&H62; do I long to&H9; hear.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Give first admittance to&H4; the ambassadors,
My news shall be the fruit to&H4; that&H62; great feast.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Thyself do grace to&H4; them, and bring them in&H5;.
He tells me my dear Gertrard he hath found
The head and source of all your son's distemper.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: I doubt it is no&H2; other but the main
His father's death, and our&Htp; hasty marriage.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Well, we&Htp; shall sift him, welcome my good friends,
Say Voltemand, what from our&Hrp; brother Norway?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Most fair return of greetings and desires;
Upon&H4; our&Htp; first, he sent out to&H9; suppress
His Nephew's levies, which&H61; to&H4; him appeared
To&H9; be a preparation gainst the Pollacke,
But better looked into, he truly found
It was against your highness, whereat grieved
That&H3; so&H52; his sickness, age, and impotence
Was falsely borne in&H4; hand, sends out arrests
On&H4; Fortenbrasse, which&H61; he in&H4; brief obeys,
Receives rebuke from Norway, and in&H4; fine,
Makes vow before his Uncle never more
To&H9; give the assay of Arms against your Majesty:
Whereon old Norway overcome with joy,
Gives him threescore thousand crowns in&H4; annual fee,
And his commission to&H9; employ those soldiers
So&H52; levied (as before) against the Pollacke,
With an entreaty herein further shone,
That&H3; it might please you to&H9; give quiet pass
Through your dominions for&H4; this enterprise
On&H4; such regards of safety and allowance
As therein are set down.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: It likes us&Hrp;, well,
And at our&Hrp; more considered time, we&Hrp; will&H1; read,
Answer, and think upon&H4; this business:
Mean time, we&Hrp; thank you for&H4; your well took labour,
Go to&H4; your rest, at night we&Htp; will&H1; feast together,
Most welcome home.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: This business is well ended.
My Liege and Madam, to&H9; expostulate
What majesty should be, what duty is,
Why day is day, night, night, and time is time,
Were nothing but to&H9; waste night, day, and time,
Therefore brevity is the soul of wit,
And tediousness the limbs and outward flourishes,
I will&H1; be brief, your noble son is mad:
Mad call I it, for&H3; to&H9; define true madness,
What is it but to&H9; be nothing else but mad,
But let that&H62; go.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: More matter with less art&H0;.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Madam, I swear I use no&H2; art&H0; at all,
That&H3; he is mad it is true, it is true, it is pity,
And pity it is it is true, a foolish figure,
But farewell it, for&H3; I will&H1; use no&H2; art&H0;.
Mad let us&Htp;, grant him then, and now remains
That&H3; we&Htp; find out the cause of this effect,
Or rather say, the cause of this defect,
For&H3; this effect defective comes by&H4; cause:
Thus it remains, and the remainder thus
Perpend,
I have a daughter, have while she is mine,
Who&H61; in&H4; her&H2; duty and obedience, mark,
Hath given me this, now gather and surmise,

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Came this from Hamlet to&H4; her&H6;?

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Good Madam stay awhile, I will&H1; be faithful,
Doubt thou the stars are fire,

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Doubt that&H3; the Sun doth move,
Doubt truth to&H9; be a liar,
But never doubt I love.
sp.p:
O dear Ophelia, I am ill at these numbers, I have not art&H0; to&H9; reckon
my groans, but that&H3; I love thee best, o most best believe it, adieu.
Thine evermore most dear Lady, whilst this machine is to&H4; him. Hamlet.
sp.l: This in&H4; obedience hath my daughter shown me,
And more about hath his solicitings
As they fell out by&H4; time, by&H4; means, and place,
All given to&H4; mine ear.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: But how hath she received his love?

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: What do you think of me?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: As of a man faithful and honourable.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: I would fain prove so&H52;, but what might you think
When I had seen this hot love on&H4; the wing,
As I perceived it (I must tell you that&H62;)
Before my daughter told me, what might you,
Or my dear Majesty your Queen here think,
If I had played the Desk, or Table book,
Or given my heart a working mute and dumb,
Or looked upon&H4; this love with idle sight,
What might you think? no&H7;, I went round to&H9; work,
And my young Mistress thus I did bespeak,
Lord Hamlet is a Prince out of thy star,
This must not be: and then I prescripts gave her&H6;
That&H3; she should lock herself from her&H2; resort,
Admit no&H2; messengers, receive no&H2; tokens,
Which&H61; done, she took the fruits of my advise:
And he repelled, a short tale to&H9; make,
Fell into a sadness, then into a fast,
Thence to&H4; a watch, thence into a weakness,
Thence to&H4; lightness, and by&H4; this declension,
Into the madness wherein now he raves,
And all we&Htp; mourn for&H5;.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Do you think this?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: It may be very like&H5;.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Hath there been such a time, I would fain know that&H62;,
That&H3; I have positively said, it is so&H52;,
When it proved otherwise?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Not that&H61; I know.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Take this, from this, if this be otherwise;
If circumstances lead me, I will&H1; find
Where truth is hid, though it were hid indeed
Within the Centre.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: How may we&Htp; try it further?

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: You know sometimes he walks four hours together
Here in&H4; the Lobby.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: So&H52; he does indeed.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: At such a time, I will&H1; lose my daughter to&H4; him,
Be you and I behind an Arras then,
Mark the encounter, if he love her&H6; not,
And be not from his reason fallen thereon
Let me be no&H2; assistant for&H4; a state
But keep a farm and carters.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: We&Hrp; will&H1; try it.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: But look where sadly the poor wretch comes reading.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Away, I do beseech you both away,

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: I will&H1; board him presently, o give me leave,
How does my good Lord Hamlet?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Well, God-a-mercy.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Do you know me my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Excellent well, you are a Fishmonger.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: Not I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Then I would you were so&H51; honest a man.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: Honest my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Aye sir to&H9; be honest as this world goes,
Is to&H9; be one man picked out of ten thousand.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: That&H62; is very true my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
For&H3; if the sun breed maggots in&H4; a dead dog, being a
god kissing carrion. Have you a daughter?

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: I have my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Let her&H6; not walk in&H4; the Sun, conception is a blessing,
But as your daughter may conceive, friend look to&H4; it.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p:
How say you by&H4; that&H62;, still harping on&H4; my daughter, yet he
knew me not at first, he said I was a Fishmonger, he is far gone,
and truly in&H4; my youth, I suffered much extremity for&H4; love, very
near this. I will&H1; speak to&H4; him again. What do you read my
Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Words, words, words.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: What is the matter my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Between who&H62;.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: I mean the matter that&H61; you read my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Slanders sir; for&H3; the satirical rogue says here, that&H3; old
men have gray beards, that&H3; their faces are wrinkled, their eyes
purging thick Amber, and plumtree gum, and that&H3; they have a plentiful lack of wit, together with most weak hams,
all which&H61; sir
though I most powerfully and potently believe, yet I hold it not
honesty to&H9; have it thus set down, for&H3; yourself sir shall grow old
as I am: if like&H4; a Crab you could go backward.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p:
Though this be madness, yet there is method in&H4; it, will&H1; you
walk out of the air my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Into my grave.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p:
Indeed that&H62; is out of the air; how pregnant sometimes
his replies are, a happiness that&H61; often madness hits on&H5;, which&H61; reason
and sanctity could not so&H51; prosperously be delivered of. I will&H1; leave
him and my daughter. My Lord, I will&H1; take my leave of you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
You cannot take from me anything that&H61; I will&H1; not more
willingly part withal: except my life, except my life, except my
life.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: Fare you well my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: These tedious old fools.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: You go to&H9; seek the Lord Hamlet, there he is.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: God save you sir.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p: My honoured Lord.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: My most dear Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: My extent good friends, how dost thou Guyldersterne?
sp.l: A Rosencraus, good lads how do you both?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: As the indifferent children of the earth.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.l: Happy, in&H4; that&H3; we&Htp; are not ever happy on&H4; Fortune's lap,
We&Htp; are not the very button.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Nor the soles of her&H2; shoe.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Neither my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Then you live about her&H2; waist , or in&H4; the middle of her&H2; favours.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p: Faith her&H2; privates we&Htp;.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
In&H4; the secret parts of Fortune, o most true, she is a strumpet,
What news?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: None my Lord, but the world is grown honest.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Then is Doomsday near, but your news is not true;
But in&H4; the beaten way of friendship, what make you at Elsonoure?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: To&H9; visit you my Lord, no&H2; other occasion.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Beggar that&H61; I am, I am ever poor in&H4; thanks, but I thank
you, and sure dear friends, my thanks are too dear a halfpenny:
were you not sent for&H5;? is it your own inclining? is it a free visitation? come, come, deal justly with me, come, come, nay speak.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p: What should we&Htp; say my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Any thing but to&H4; the purpose: you were sent for&H5;, and there is
a kind of confession in&H4; your looks, which&H61; your modesties have not
craft enough to&H9; colour, I know the good King and Queen have
sent for&H4; you.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: To&H4; what end my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
That&H62; you must teach me: but let me conjure you, by&H4; the
rights of our&Htp; fellowship, by&H4; the consonancy of our&Htp; youth, by&H4; the
obligation of our&Htp; ever preserved love; and by&H4; what more dear a
better proposer can charge you withal, be even and direct with
me whether you were sent for&H5; or no&H5;.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: What say you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Nay then I have an eye of you? if you love me hold not off.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p: My Lord we&Htp; were sent for&H5;.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I will&H1; tell you why, so&H3; shall my anticipation prevent your
discovery, and your secrecy to&H4; the King and Queen moult no&H2; feather, I have of late, but wherefore I know not, lost all my mirth,
forgone all custom of exercises: and indeed it goes so&H51; heavily with
my disposition, that&H3; this goodly frame the earth, seems to&H4; me a
sterile promontory, this most excellent Canopy the air, look
you, this brave overhanging firmament, this majestic roof fretted with golden fire, why it appeareth nothing to&H4; me but a foul
and pestilent congregation of vapours. What piece of work is a
man, how noble in&H4; reason, how infinite in&H4; faculties, in&H4; form and
moving, how express and admirable in&H4; action, how like&H4; an Angel in&H4; apprehension, how like&H4; a God: the beauty of the world; the
paragon of Animals; and yet to&H4; me, what is this Quintessence of
dust: man delights not me, nor women neither, though by&H4; your
smiling, you seem to&H9; say so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: My Lord, there was no&H2; such stuff in&H4; my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Why did ye laugh then, when I said man delights not me.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
To&H9; think my Lord if you delight not in&H4; man, what Lenten
entertainment the players shall receive from you, we&Htp; coated them
on&H4; the way, and hither are they coming to&H9; offer you service.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
He that&H61; plays the King shall be welcome, his Majesty shall
have tribute on&H4; me, the adventurous Knight shall use his foil and
target, the Lover shall not sigh gratis, the humorous Man shall end
his part in&H4; peace, and the Lady shall say her&H2; mind freely: or the
black verse shall halt for&H4; it. What players are they?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Even those you were wont to&H9; take such delight in&H5;, the Tragedians of the City.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: How chances it they travail? their residence both in&H4; reputation, and profit was better both ways.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
I think their inhibition, comes by&H4; the means of the late
innovation.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Do they hold the same estimation they did when I was in&H4;
the City; are they so&H51; followed.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: No&H7; indeed are they not.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
It is not very strange, for&H3; my Uncle is King of Denmarke, and
those that&H61; would make mouths at him while my father lived, give
twenty, forty, fifty, a hundred ducats apiece, for&H4; his Picture
in&H4; little, 'sblood there is something in&H4; this more than natural, if
Philosophy could find it out.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p: There are the players.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Gentlemen you are welcome to&H4; Elsonoure, your hands come
then, the appurtenance of welcome is fashion and ceremony; let
me comply with you in&H4; this garb: let me extent to&H4; the players,
which&H61; I tell you must show fairly outwards, should more appear like&H4; entertainment than yours? you are welcome: but my
Uncle-father, and Aunt-mother, are deceived.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p: In&H4; what my dear Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I am but mad North North west; when the wind is Southerly, I know a Hawk, from a hand saw.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: Well be with you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Hark you Guyldensterne, and you too, at each ear a hearer,
that&H62; great baby you see there is not yet out of his swaddling clouts.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Happily he is the second time come to&H4; them, for&H3; they say an
old man is twice a child.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I will&H1; prophesy, he comes to&H9; tell me of the players, mark it,
You say right sir, a Monday morning, it was then indeed.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: My Lord I have news to&H9; tell you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
My Lord I have news to&H9; tell you: when Rossius was an Actor
in&H4; Rome.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: The Actors are come hither my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Buzz, buzz.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: Upon&H4; my honour.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Then came each Actor on&H4; his Ass.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p:
The best actors in&H4; the world, either for&H4; Tragedy, Comedy,
History, Pastoral, Pastoral Comical, Historical Pastoral, scene
individible, or Poem unlimited. Sceneca cannot be too heavy, nor
Plautus too light for&H4; the law of writ, and the liberty: these are the
only men.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: O Ieptha Judge of Israell, what a treasure hadst thou?

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: What a treasure had he my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why one fair daughter and no&H2; more, the which&H61; he loved
passing well.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: Still on&H4; my daughter.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Am I not in&H4; the right old Ieptha?

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: If you call me Ieptha my Lord, I have a daughter that&H61; I love passing well.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Nay that&H62; follows not.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: What follows then my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why as by&H4; lot God wot, and then you know it came to&H9;
pass, as most like&H4; it was; the first row of the pious chanson will&H1;
show you more, for&H3; look where my abridgement comes.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
You are welcome masters, welcome all, I am glad to&H9; see thee
well, welcome good friends, o old friend, why thy face is valanced since I saw thee last, comest thou to&H9; beard me in&H4; Denmark?
what my young Lady and mistress, by&H4; lady your Ladyship is
nearer to&H4; heaven, than when I saw you last by&H4; the altitude of a
chopine, pray God your voice like&H4; a piece of uncurrent gold,
be not cracked within the ring: masters you are all welcome,
we&Htp; will&H1; even to&H4; it like&H4; friendly Falconers, fly at anything we&Htp; see,
we&Htp; will&H1; have a speech straight, come give us&Htp;, a taste of your quality,
come a passionate speech.

sp.speaker: 1st play.
sp.p: What speech my good Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I heard thee speak me a speech once, but it was never acted,
or if it was, not above once, for&H3; the play I remember pleased not
the million, it was caviar to&H4; the general, but it was as I received
it and others, whose judgments in&H4; such matters cried in&H4; the top
of mine, an excellent play, well digested in&H4; the scenes, set down
with as much modesty as cunning. I remember one said there
were no&H2; sallets in&H4; the lines, to&H9; make the matter savoury, nor no&H2;
matter in&H4; the phrase that&H61; might indite the author of affection,
but called it an honest method, as wholesome as sweet, and by&H4; very
much, more handsome than fine: one speech in&H4; it I chiefly loved,
it was Aeneas talk to&H4; Dido, and there about of it especially when he
speaks of Priams slaughter, if it live in&H4; your memory begin at
this line, let me see, let me see, the rugged Pirbus like&H4; The ircanian
beast, it is not so&H52;, it begins with Pirrhus, the rugged Pirrhus, he whose
sable Arms,
sp.l: Black as his purpose did the night resemble,
When he lay couched in&H4; the ominous horse,
Hath now this dread and black complexion smeared,
With heraldry more dismal head to&H4; foot,
Now is he total Gules horridly tricked
With blood of fathers, mothers, daughters, sons,
Baked and impasted with the parching streets
That&H61; lend a tyrannous and a damned light
To&H4; their Lord's murther, roasted in&H4; wrath and fire,
And thus oversized with coagulate gore,
With eyes like&H4; Carbuncles, the hellish Phirrhus
Old grandsire Priam seeks; so&H52; proceed you.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: Foregod my Lord well spoken, with good accent and good discretion.

sp.speaker: 1st play.
sp.l: Anon he finds him,
Striking too short at Greeks, his antic sword
Rebellious to&H4; his arm, lies where it falls,
Repugnant to&H9; command; unequal matched,
Pirrhus at Priam drives, in&H4; rage strikes wide,
But with the whiff and wind of his fell sword,
The unnerved father falls:
Seeming to&H9; feel this blow, with flaming top
Stoops to&H4; his base; and with a hideous crash
Takes prisoner Pirrhus ear, for&H3; lo his sword
Which&H61; was declining on&H4; the milky head
Of reverent Priam, seemed in&H4; the air to&H9; stick,
So&H52; as a painted tyrant Pirrhus stood
Like&H4; a neutral to&H4; his will&H0; and matter,
Did nothing:
But as we&Htp; often see against some storm,
A silence in&H4; the heavens, the rack stand still,
The bold winds speechless, and the orb below
As hush as death, anon the dreadful thunder
Doth rend the region, so&H52; after Pirrhus pause,
A roused vengeance sets him new a-work,
And never did the Cyclops hammers fall,
On&H4; Marses Armour forged for&H4; proof uterine,
With less remorse than Pirrhus bleeding sword
Now falls on&H4; Priam.
Out, out, thou strumpet Fortune, all you gods,
In&H4; general synod take away her&H2; power,
Break all the spokes, and follies from her&H2; wheel,
And bowl the round nave down the hill of heaven
As low as to&H4; the fiends.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: This is too long.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: It shall to&H4; the barbers with your beard; prithee say on&H5;, he is for&H4; a Jig, or a tale of bawdry, or he sleeps, say on&H5;, come to&H4; Hecuba.

sp.speaker: 1st play.
sp.l: But who&H62;, a woe, had seen the mobled Queen,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: The mobled Queen.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: That&H62; is good.

sp.speaker: 1st play.
sp.l: Run barefoot up&H5; and down, threatening the flames
With Bison rheum, a clout upon&H4; that&H62; head
Where late the Diadem stood, and for&H4; a robe,
About her&H2; lank and all ore-teamed loins,
A blanket in&H4; the alarm of fear caught up&H5;,
Who&H61; this had seen, with tongue in&H4; venom steeped,
Gainst fortunes state would treason have pronounced;
But
if the gods themselves did see her&H6; then,
When she saw Pirrhus make malicious sport
In&H4; mincing with his sword her&H2; husband limbs,
The instant burst of clamour that&H61; she made,
Unless things mortal move them not at all,
Would have made milch the burning eyes of heaven
And passion in&H4; the gods.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p:
Look where he has not turned his colour, and has tears in&H4; his
eyes, prithee no&H2; more.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
It is well, I will&H1; have thee speak out the rest of this soon,
Good my Lord will&H1; you see the players well bestowed; do you
hear, let them be well used, for&H3; they are the abstract and brief
Chronicles of the time; after your death you were better have a
bad Epitaph than their ill report while you live.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: My Lord, I will&H1; use them according to&H4; their desert.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
God's bodkin man, much better, use every man after his desert, and who&H62; shall scape whipping, use them
after your own honour and dignity, the less they deserve the more merit is in&H4; your bounty. Take them in&H5;.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: Come sirs.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Follow him friends, we&Htp; will&H1; hear a play tomorrow; dost thou
hear me old friend, can you play the murther of Gonzago?

sp.speaker: 1st play.
sp.p: Aye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
We&Htp; will&H1; have it tomorrow night, you could for&H4; need study
a speech of some dozen lines, or sixteen lines, which&H61; I would set
down and insert in&H4; it, could you not?

sp.speaker: 1st play.
sp.p: Aye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Very well, follow that&H62; Lord, and look you mock him not.
My good friends, I will&H1; leave you till night, you are welcome to&H4; Elsonoure.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Aye so&H3; Goodbye to&H4; you, now I am alone,
O what a rogue and peasant slave am I.
Is it not monstrous that&H3; this player here
But in&H4; a fiction, in&H4; a dream of passion
Could force his soul so&H51; to&H4; his own conceit
That&H3; from her&H2; working all the visage wand,
Tears in&H4; his eyes, distraction in&H4; his aspect,
A broken voice, an his whole function suiting
With forms to&H4; his conceit; and all for&H4; nothing,
For&H4; Hecuba.
What is Hecuba to&H4; him, or he to&H4; her&H6;,
That&H3; he should weep for&H4; her&H6;? what would he do
Had he the motive, and that&H62; for&H4; passion
That&H61; I have? he would drown the stage with tears,
And cleave the general ear with horrid speech,
Make mad the guilty, and appal the free,
Confound the ignorant, and amaze indeed
The very faculties of eyes and ears; yet I,
A dull and muddy metalled rascal peak,
Like&H4; Iohn-a-dreames, unpregnant of my cause,
And can say nothing; no&H7; not for&H4; a King,
Upon&H4; whose property and most dear life,
A damned defeat was made: am I a coward,
Who&H62; calls me villain, breaks my pate across,
Plucks off my beard, and blows it in&H4; my face,
Tweaks me by&H4; the nose, gives me the lie in&H4; the throat
As deep as to&H4; the lunges, who&H62; does me this,
Ha, 'swounds I should take it: for&H3; it cannot be
But I am pigeon livered, and lack gall
To&H9; make oppression bitter, or ere this
I should have fatted all the region kites
With this slave's offal, bloody, bawdy villain,
Remorseless, treacherous, lecherous, kindless villain.
Why what an Ass am I, this is most brave,
That&H3; I the son of a dear murthered,
Prompted to&H4; my revenge by&H4; heaven and hell,
Must like&H4; a whore unpack my heart with words,
And fall a-cursing like&H4; a very drab; a stallion, fie upon&H4; it, foh.
About my brains; hum, I have heard,
That&H3; guilty creatures sitting at a play,
Have by&H4; the very cunning of the scene,
Been struck so&H51; to&H4; the soul, that&H3; presently
They have proclaimed their malefactions:
