For&H3; murther, though it have no&H2; tongue will&H1; speak
With most miraculous organ: I will&H1; have these Players
Play something like&H4; the murther of my father
Before mine Uncle, I will&H1; observe his looks,
I will&H1; tent him to&H4; the quick, if he do blench
I know my course. The spirit that&H61; I have seen
May be a deal, and the deal hath power
To&H9; assume a pleasing shape, yea, and perhaps,
Out of my weakness, and my melancholy,
As he is very potent with such spirits,
Abuses me to&H9; damn me; I will&H1; have grounds
More relative than this, the play is the thing
Wherein I will&H1; catch the conscience of the King.

stage.l: Enter King, Queene, Polonius, Ophelia, Rosencraus, Guyldensterne, Lords.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: And can you by&H4; no&H2; drift of conference
Get from him why he puts on&H5; this confusion,
Grating so&H51; harshly all his days of quiet
With turbulent and dangerous lunacy?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: He does confess he feels himself distracted,
But from what cause, he will&H1; by&H4; no&H2; means speak.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.l: Nor do we&Htp; find him forward to&H9; be sounded,
But with a crafty madness keeps aloof
When we&Htp; would bring him on&H5; to&H4; some confession
Of his true state.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Did he receive you well?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Most like&H4; a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.l: But with much forcing of his disposition.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Niggard of question, but of our&Htp; demands
Most free in&H4; his reply.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Did you assay him to&H4; any pastime?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Madam, it so&H52; fell out that&H3; certain Players
We&Htp; ore-raught on&H4; the way, of these we&Htp; told him,
And there did seem in&H4; him a kind of joy
To&H9; hear of it: they are here about the Court,
And as I think, they have already order
This night to&H9; play before him.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: It is most true,
And he beseeched me to&H9; entreat your Majesties
To&H9; hear and see the matter.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: With all my heart,
And it doth much content me
To&H9; hear him so&H52; inclined.
Good gentlemen give him a further edge,
And drive his purpose into these delights.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: We&Htp; shall my Lord.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Sweet Gertrard, leave us&Htp;, two,
For&H3; we&Htp; have closely sent for&H4; Hamlet hither,
That&H3; he as it were by&H4; accident, may here
Affront Ophelia; her&H2; father and myself,
We&Htp; will&H1; so&H52; bestow ourselves, that&H3; seeing unseen,
We&Htp; may of their encounter frankly judge,
And gather by&H4; him as he is behaved,
If it be the affliction of his love or no&H5;
That&H61; thus he suffers for&H5;.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: I shall obey you.
And for&H4; your part Ophelia, I do wish
That&H3; your good beauties be the happy cause
Of Hamlets wildness, so&H52; shall I hope your virtues,
Will&H1; bring him to&H4; his wonted way again,
To&H4; both your honours.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: Madam, I wish it may.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Ophelia walk you here, gracious so&H3; please you,
We&Htp; will&H1; bestow ourselves; read on&H4; this book,
That&H3; show of such an exercise may colour
Your lowliness; we&Htp; are oft too blame in&H4; this,
It is too much proved, that&H3; with devotions visage
And pious action, we&Htp; do sugar over
The devil himself.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: O it is too true,
How smart a lash that&H62; speech doth give my conscience.
The harlot's cheek beautied with plastering art&H0;,
Is not more ugly to&H4; the thing that&H61; helps it,
Than is my deed to&H4; my most painted word:
O heavy burthen.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: I hear him coming, with-draw my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: To&H9; be, or not to&H9; be, that&H62; is the question,
Whether it is nobler in&H4; the mind to&H9; suffer
The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune,
Or to&H9; take Arms against a sea of troubles,
And by&H4; opposing, end them, to&H9; die to&H9; sleep
No&H2; more, and by&H4; a sleep, to&H9; say we&Htp; end
The heartache, and the thousand natural shocks
That&H61; flesh is heir to&H5;; it is a consummation
Devoutly to&H9; be wished to&H9; die to&H9; sleep,
To&H9; sleep, perchance to&H9; dream, aye there is the rub,
For&H3; in&H4; that&H62; sleep of death what dreams may come
When we&Htp; have shuffled off this mortal coil
Must give us&Htp;, pause, there is the respect
That&H61; makes calamity of so&H51; long life:
For&H3; who&H62; would bear the whips and scorns of time,
The oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumely,
The pangs of despised love, the laws delay,
The insolence of office, and the spurns
That&H61; patient merit of the unworthy takes,
When he himself might his quietus make
With a bare bodkin; who&H62; would fardels bear,
To&H9; grunt and sweat under a weary life,
But that&H3; the dread of something after death,
The undiscovered country, from whose borne
No&H2; traveler returns, puzzles the will&H0;,
And makes us&Htp;, rather bear those ills we&Htp; have,
Than fly to&H4; others that&H61; we&Htp; know not of.
Thus conscience does make cowards,
And thus the native hue of resolution
Is sickled over with the pale cast of thought,
And enterprises of great pitch and moment,
With this regard their currents turn awry,
And lose the name of action. Soft you now,
The fair Ophelia, Nymph in&H4; thy orisons
Be all my sins remembered.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: Good my Lord,
How does your honour for&H4; this many a day?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I humbly thank you well.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: My Lord, I have remembrances of yours
That&H61; I have longed long to&H9; redeliver,
I pray you now receive them.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No&H7;, not I, I never gave you aught.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: My honoured Lord, you know right well you did,
And with them words of so&H51; sweet breath composed
As made these things more rich, their perfume lost,
Take these again, for&H3; to&H4; the noble mind
Rich gifts wax poor when givers prove unkind,
There my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Ha, ha, are you honest.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Are you fair?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: What means your Lordship?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
That&H3; if you be honest and fair, you should admit
no&H2; discourse to&H4; your beauty.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p:
Could beauty my Lord have better commerce
Than with honesty?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Aye truly, for&H3; the power of beauty will&H1; sooner transform honesty from what it is to&H4; a bawd, than the force of honesty can translate
beauty into his likeness, this was sometime a paradox, but now the
time gives it proof, I did love you once.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p: Indeed my Lord you made me believe so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
You should not have believed me, for&H3; vertue cannot so&H51;
inoculate our&Htp; old stock, but we&Htp; shall relish of it, I loved you not.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: I was the more deceived.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Get thee a Nunnery, why wouldst thou be a breeder of sinners, I am myself. indifferent honest, but yet I could accuse me of
such things, that&H3; it were better my Mother had not borne me: I am
very proud, revengeful, ambitious, with more offences at my beck,
than I have thoughts to&H9; put them in&H5;, imagination to&H9; give them shape,
or time to&H9; act them in&H5;: what should such fellows as I do crawling between earth and heaven, we&Htp; are arrant knaues, believe none of us&Htp;,
go thy ways to&H4; a Nunnery. Where is your father?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: At home my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Let the doors be shut upon&H4; him,
That&H3; he may play the fool nowhere but in&H4; his own house,
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: O help him you sweet heavens.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
If thou dost marry, I will&H1; give thee this plague for&H4; thy dowry, be thou as chaste as ice, as pure as snow, thou shalt not escape calumny; get
thee to&H4; a Nunnery, farewell. Or if thou wilt needs marry,
marry a fool, for&H3; wise men know well enough what monsters you
make of them: to&H4; a Nunnery go, and quickly too, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: Heavenly powers restore him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I have heard of your paintings well enough, God hath given you one face, and you make yourselves another, you gig and amble, and you list
you nickname God's creatures, and make your wantonness ignorance; go to&H5;, I will&H1; no&H2; more on&H4; it, it hath made me mad,
I say we&Htp; will&H1; have no&H2; more marriage, those that&H61; are married already, all
but one shall live, the rest shall keep as they are: to&H4; a Nunnery go.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: O what a noble mind is here overthrown!
The Courtier's, soldier's, scholar's, eye, tongue, sword,
The expectation, and Rose of the fair state,
The glass of fashion, and the mould of form,
The observed of all observers, quite quite down,
And I of Ladies most deject and wretched,
That&H61; sucked the honey of his musicked vows;
Now see what noble and most sovereign reason
Like&H4; sweet bells jangled out of time, and harsh,
That&H62; unmatched form, and stature of blown youth
Blasted with ecstasy, o woe is me
To&H9; have seen what I have seen, see what I see.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Love, his affections do not that&H62; way tend,
Nor what he spake, though it lacked form a little,
Was not like&H4; madness, there is something in&H4; his soul
Over which&H61; his melancholy sits on&H4; brood,
And I do doubt, the hatch and the disclose
Will&H1; be some danger; which&H61; for&H3; to&H9; prevent,
I have in&H4; quick determination
Thus set it down: he shall with speed to&H4; England,
For&H4; the demand of our&Hrp; neglected tribute,
Haply the seas, and countries different,
With variable objects, shall expel
This something settled matter in&H4; his heart,
Whereon his brains still beating
Puts him thus from fashion of himself.
What think you on&H4; it?

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: It shall do well.
But yet do I believe the origin and commencement of his grief,
Sprung from neglected love: How now Ophelia?
You need not tell us&Htp;, what Lord Hamlet said,
We&Htp; heard it all: my Lord, do as you please,
But if you hold it fit, after the play,
Let his Queen-mother all alone entreat him
To&H9; show his grief, let her&H6; be round with him,
And I will&H1; be placed (so&H3; please you) in&H4; the ear
Of all their conference, if she find him not,
To&H4; England send him: or confine him where
Your wisdom best shall think.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: It shall be so&H52;,
Madness in&H4; great ones must not unmatched go.

stage.l: Enter Hamlet, and three of the Players.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Speak the speech I pray you as I paramount it to&H4; you, trippingly on&H4; the tongue, but if you mouth it as many of our&Htp; Players do,
I had as lief the town crier spoke my lines, nor do not saw the air
too much with your hand thus, but use all gently, for&H3; in&H4; the very torrent tempest, and as I may say, whirlwind of your passion, you must
acquire and beget a temperance, that&H61; may give it smoothness, o it
offends me to&H4; the soul, to&H9; hear a robustious periwig-pated fellow
tear a passion to&H4; totters, to&H4; very rags, to&H9; split the ears of the groundlings, who&H61; for&H4; the most part are capable of nothing but inexplicable dumb shows, and noise:
I would have such a fellow whipped for&H4;
overdoing Termagant, it out Herods Herod, pray you avoid it.

sp.speaker: 1st play.
sp.p: I warrant your honour.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Be not too tame neither, but let your own discretion be
your tutor, suit the action to&H4; the word, the word to&H4; the action, with
this special observance, that&H3; you ore-steppe not the modesty of nature: For&H3; anything so&H51; over-done, is from the purpose of playing,
whose end both at the first, and now, was and is, to&H9; hold as it were
the Mirror up&H5; to&H4; nature, to&H9; show vertue her&H2; feature; scorn her&H2; own
Image, and the very age and body of the time his form and pressure:
Now this over-done, or come tardy off, though it makes the unskilful laugh, cannot but make the judicious grieve, the censure of
which&H61; one, must in&H4; your allowance ore-weigh a whole Theatre of others. O there be Players that&H61; I have seen play, and heard others
praised, and that&H62; highly, not to&H9; speak it profanely, that&H3; neither having the accent of Christians, nor the gate of Christian, Pagan, nor
man, have so&H51; strutted and bellowed, that&H3; I have thought some of Nature's Journeymen had made men, and not made them well, they imitated humanity so&H51; abominably.

sp.speaker: 1st play.
sp.p: I hope we&Htp; have reformed that&H62; indifferently with us&Htp;,.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
O reform it altogether, and let those that&H61; play your clowns
speak no&H2; more than is set down for&H4; them, for&H3; there be of them that&H61;
will&H1; themselves laugh, to&H9; set on&H5; some quantity of barren spectators
to&H9; laugh too, though in&H4; the mean time, some necessary question of
the play be then to&H9; be considered, that&H62; is villainous, and shows a most
pitiful ambition in&H4; the fool that&H61; uses it : go make you ready. How
now my Lord, will&H1; the King hear this piece of work?

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: And the Queen too, and that&H62; presently.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Bid the Players make haste. Will&H1; you two help to&H9; hasten them.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Aye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What ho, Horatio.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Here sweet Lord, at your service.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Horatio, thou art even as just a man
As ere my conversation coped withal.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: O my dear Lord.
Nay, do not think I flatter,
For&H3; what advancement may I hope from thee
That&H61; no&H2; revenue hast but thy good spirits
To&H9; feed and clothe thee, why should the poor be flattered?
No&H7;, let the candied tongue lick absurd pomp,
And crook the pregnant hinges of the knee
Where thrift may follow fawning; dost thou hear,
Since my dear soul was mistress of her&H2; choice,
And could of men distinguish her&H2; election,
She hath sealed thee for&H4; herself, for&H3; thou hast been
As one in&H4; suffering all that&H61; suffers nothing,
A man that&H61; Fortune's buffets and rewards
Hast taken with equal thanks; and blessed are those
Whose blood and judgment are so&H51; well commeddled,
That&H3; they are not a pipe for&H4; Fortune's finger
To&H9; sound what stop she please: give me that&H62; man
That&H61; is not passion's slave, and I will&H1; wear him
In&H4; my heart's core, aye in&H4; my heart of heart
As I do thee. Something too much of this,
There is a play tonight before the King,
One scene of it comes near the circumstance
Which&H61; I have told thee of my father's death,
I prithee when thou seest that&H62; act afoot,
Even with the very comment of thy soul
Observe my Uncle, if his occulted guilt
Do not itself unkennel in&H4; one speech,
It is a damned ghost that&H61; we&Htp; have seen,
And my imaginations are as foul
As Vulcans stithy; give him heedful note,
For&H3; I mine eyes will&H1; rivet to&H4; his face,
And after we&Htp; will&H1; both our&Htp; judgments join
In&H4; censure of his seeming.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Well my lord,
If he steal aught the whilst this play is playing
And scape detected, I will&H1; pay the theft.

stage.l: Enter Trumpets and Kettle Drummes,King, Queene,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: They are coming to&H4; the play. I must be idle,
Get you a place.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: How fares our&Htp; cousin Hamlet?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Excellent yfaith,
Of the Chameleon's dish, I eat the air,
Promise-crammed, you cannot feed Capons so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
I have nothing with this answer Hamlet,
These words are not mine.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
No&H7;, nor mine now my Lord.
You played once in&H4; the University you say,

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: That&H62; did I my Lord, and was accounted a good Actor,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What did you enact?

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p:
I did enact Julius Caesar, I was killed in&H4; the Capital,
Brutus killed me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
It was a brute part of him to&H9; kill so&H51; capital a calf there,
Be the Players ready?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Aye my Lord, they stay upon&H4; your patience.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Come hither my dear Hamlet, sit by&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: No&H7; good mother, here is mettle more attractive.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: O ho, do you mark that&H62;.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Lady shall I lie in&H4; your lap?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p: No&H7; my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Do you think I meant country matters?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p: I think nothing my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: That&H62; is a fair thought to&H9; lie between maids' legs.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p: What is my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p: You are merry my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Who&H62; I?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p: Aye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
O God your only Jig-maker, what should a man do but
be merry, for&H3; look you how cheerfully my mother looks, and my
father died within these two hours.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p: Nay, it is twice two months my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
So&H51; long, nay then let the devil wear black, for&H3; I will&H1; have a
suit of sables; o heavens, die two months ago, and not forgotten yet,
then there is hope a great man's memory may outlive his life half a
year, but ber Lady he must build Churches then, or else shall he suffer
not thinking on&H5;, with the Hobby-horse, whose Epitaph is, for&H3; o, for&H3;
o, the hobby-horse is forgot.

stage.l: The Trumpets sounds. Dumbe show followes.
Enter a King and a Queene, the Queene embracing him, and he her&H6;,he
takes her&H6; up&H5;, and declines his head upon&H4; her&H2; necke,he lyes him downe upon&H4; a bancke of flowers, she seeing him asleepe, leaues him: anon come in&H4; an
other man, takes off his crowne, kisses it, pours poyson in&H4; the sleeper's eares,
and leaues him: the Queene returnes, finds the King dead, makes passionate
action, the poysner with some three or foure come in&H5; againe, seeme to&H9; condole with her&H6;, the dead body is carried away, the poysner wooes the Queene
with gifts, shee seemes harsh awhile, but in&H4; the end accepts loue.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p: What means this my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Marry this munching Mallico, it means mischief.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p: Belike this show imports the argument of the play.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: We&Htp; shall know by&H4; this fellow,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: The Players cannot keep, they will&H1; tell all.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p: Will&H1; he tell us&Htp;, what this show meant?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Aye, or any show that&H61; you will&H1; show him, be not you ashamed
to&H9; show, he will&H1; not shame to&H9; tell you what it means.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p: You are naught, you are naught, I will&H1; mark the play.

sp.speaker: 4th play.
sp.l: For&H4; us&Htp;, and for&H4; our&Htp; Tragedy,
Here stooping to&H4; your clemency,
We&Htp; beg your hearing patiently.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Is this a Prologue, or the posy of a ring?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p: It is brief my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: As woman's love.

sp.speaker: 1st play.
sp.l: Full thirty times hath Phebus cart gone round
Neptunes salt wash, and Tellus orbed the ground,
And thirty dozen Moons with borrowed sheen
About the world have times twelve thirties been
Since love our&Htp; hearts, and Hymen did our&Htp; hands
Unite commutual in&H4; most sacred bands.

sp.speaker: 2nd play.
sp.l: So&H51; many journeys may the Sun and Moon
Make us&Htp;, again count over ere love be done,
But woe is me, you are so&H51; sick of late,
So&H51; far from cheer, and from our&Htp; former state,
That&H3; I distrust you, yet though I distrust,
Discomfort you my Lord it nothing must.
For&H3; women fear too much, even as they love,
And women's fear and love hold quantity,
Either none, in&H4; neither aught, or in&H4; extremity,
Now what my Lord is proof hath made you know,
And as my love is sized, my fear is so&H52;,
Where love is great, the littlest doubts are fear,
Where little fears grow great, great love grows there.

sp.speaker: 1st play.
sp.l: Faith I must leave thee love, and shortly too,
My operant powers their functions leave to&H9; do,
And thou shalt live in&H4; this fair world behind,
Honoured, beloved, and haply one as kind,
For&H4; husband shalt thou.

sp.speaker: 2nd play.
sp.l: O confound the rest,
Such love must needs be treason in&H4; my breast,
In&H4; second husband let me be accursed,
None wed the second, but who&H61; killed the first.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
That&H62; is
wormwood

sp.speaker: 2nd play.
sp.l: The instances that&H61; second marriage move
Are base respects of thrift, but none of love,
A second time I kill my husband dead,
When second husband kisses me in&H4; bed.

sp.speaker: 1st play.
sp.l: I do believe you think what now you speak,
But what we&Htp; do determine, oft we&Htp; break,
Purpose is but the slave to&H4; memory,
Of violent birth, but poor validity,
Which&H61; now the fruit unripe sticks on&H4; the tree,
But fall unshaken when they mellow be.
Most necessary it is that&H3; we&Htp; forget
To&H9; pay ourselves what to&H4; ourselves is debt,
What to&H4; ourselves in&H4; passion we&Htp; propose,
The passion ending, doth the purpose lose,
The violence of either, grief, or joy,
Their own enactures with themselves destroy,
Where joy most revels, grief doth most lament,
Grief joy, joy griefs, on&H4; slender accident,
This world is not for&H4; aye, nor it is not strange,
That&H3; even our&Htp; loves should with our&Htp; fortunes change:
For&H3; it is a question left us&Htp;, yet to&H9; prove,
Whether love lead fortune, or else fortune love.
The great man down, you mark his favourite flies,
The poor advanced, makes friends of enemies,
And hitherto doth love on&H4; fortune tend,
For&H3; who&H61; not needs, shall never lack a friend,
And who&H61; in&H4; want a hollow friend doth try,
Directly seasons him his enemy.
But orderly to&H9; end where I begun,
Our&Htp; wills and fates do so&H51; contrary run,
That&H3; our&Htp; devices still are overthrown,
Our&Htp; thoughts are ours&Htp;, their ends none of our&Htp; own,
So&H52; think thou wilt no&H2; second husband wed,
But die thy thoughts when thy first Lord is dead.

sp.speaker: 2nd play.
sp.l: Nor earth to&H4; me give food, nor heaven light,
Sport and repose lock from me day and night,
To&H4; desperation turn my trust and hope,
And Anchor's cheer in&H4; prison be my scope,
Each opposite that&H61; blanks the face of joy,
Meet what I would have well, and it destroy,
Both here and hence pursue me lasting strife,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: If she should break it now.

sp.speaker: 2nd play.
sp.l: If once I be a widow, ever I be a wife.

sp.speaker: 1st play.
sp.l: It is deeply sworn, sweet leave me here a while,
My spirits grow dull, and fain I would beguile
The tedious day with sleep.

sp.speaker: 2nd play.
sp.l: Sleep rock thy brain,
And never come mischance between us&Htp;, twain.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Madam, how like&H1; you this play?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: The Lady doth protest too much methinks.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: O but she will&H1; keep her&H2; word.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Have you heard the argument? is there no&H2; offence in&H4; it?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: No&H7;, no&H7;, they do but jest, poison in&H4; jest, no&H2; offence in&H4; the world.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: What do you call the play?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
The Mousetrap, marry how tropically, this play is the Image
of a murther done in&H4; Vienna, Gonzago is the Duke's name, his wife
Baptista, you shall see anon, it is a knavish piece of work, but what of
that&H62;? your Majesty, and we&Htp; that&H61; have free souls, it touches us&Htp;, not,
let the galled Jade winch, our&Htp; withers are unwrung. This is one Lucianus, Nephew to&H4; the King.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p: You are as good as a Chorus my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I could interpret between you and your love
If I could see the puppets dallying.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p: You are keen my lord, you are keen.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: It would cost you a groaning to&H9; take off mine edge.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p: Still better and worse.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
So&H52; you mistake your husbands. Begin murtherer, leave
thy damnable faces and begin, come, the croaking Raven doth bellow
for&H4; revenge.

sp.speaker: 3rd play.
sp.l: Thoughts black, hands apt, drugs fit, and time agreeing,
Considerate season else no&H2; creature seeing,
Thou mixture rank, of midnight weeds collected,
With Hecats ban thrice blasted, thrice infected,
Thy natural magic, and dire property,
On&H4; wholesome life usurps immediately.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
He poisons him in&H4; the Garden for&H4; his estate, his name is Gonzago, the story is extant, and written in&H4; very choice Italian, you shall see
anon how the murtherer gets the love of Gonzagoes wife.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p: The King rises.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: How fares my Lord?

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: Give over the play.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Give me some light, away.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: Lights, lights, lights.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why let the stricken Deer go weep,
The Heart ungalled play,
For&H3; some must watch while some must sleep,
Thus runs the world away.
sp.p:
Would not this sir and a forest of feathers, if the rest of my fortunes turn Turk with me, with provincial
Roses on&H4; my razed shoes, get me a fellowship in&H4; a cry of players?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Half a share.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
A whole one I.
For&H3; thou dost know o Damon dear
This Realm dismantled was
Of Jove himself, and now reigns here
A very very peacock.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: You might have rhymed.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
O good Horatio, I will&H1; take the Ghost's word for&H4; a thousand
pound. Didst perceive?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Very well my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Upon&H4; the talk of the poisoning.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: I did very well note him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Ah ha, come some music, come the Recorders,
For&H3; if the King like&H1; not the Comedy,
Why then belike he likes it not perdy.
Come, some music.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p: Good my Lord, vouchsafe me a word with you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Sir a whole history.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p: The King sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Aye sir, what of him?

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p: Is in&H4; his retirement marvelous distempered.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: With drink sir?

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p: No&H7; my Lord, with choler,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Your wisdom should show itself more richer to&H9; signify
this to&H4; the Doctor, for&H3;, for&H4; me to&H9; put him to&H4; his purgation, would
perhaps plunge him into more choler.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p:
Good my Lord put your discourse into some frame,
And stare not so&H51; wildly from my affair.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I am tame sir, pronounce.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p: The Queen your mother in&H4; most great affliction of spirit, hath sent me to&H4; you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: You are welcome.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p:
Nay good my Lord, this courtesy is not of the right breed, if
it shall please you to&H9; make me a wholesome answer, I will&H1; do your
mother's commandment, if not, your pardon and my return, shall
be the end of business.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Sir I cannot.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: What my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Make you a wholesome answer, my wit is diseased, but sir, such
answer as I can make, you shall command, or rather as you say, my
mother, therefore no&H2; more, but to&H4; the matter, my mother you say.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Then thus she says, your behaviour hath struck her&H6; into amazement and admiration.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
O wonderful son that&H61; can so&H51; astonish a mother, but is there
no&H2; sequel at the heels of this mother's admiration, impart.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: She desires to&H9; speak with you in&H4; her&H2; closet ere you go to&H4; bed.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
We&Hrp; shall obey, were she ten times our&Hrp; mother, have you any
further trade with us&Hrp;,?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: My Lord, you once did love me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: And do still by&H4; these pickers and stealers.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Good my Lord, what is your cause of distemper, you do surely bar the door upon&H4; your own liberty if you deny your griefs to&H4;
your friend.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Sir I lack advancement.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: How can that&H62; be, when you have the voice of the King himself for&H4; your succession in&H4; Denmarke.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Aye sir, but while the grass grows, the proverb is something
musty, o the Recorders, let me see one, to&H9; withdraw with you, why
do you go about to&H9; recover the wind of me, as if you would drive
me into a toil?

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p: O my lord, if my duty be too bold, my love is too unmannerly.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I do not well understand that&H62;, will&H1; you play upon&H4; this pipe?

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p: My lord I cannot.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I pray you.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p: Believe me I cannot.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I do beseech you.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p: I know no&H2; touch of it my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
It is as easy as lying; govern these ventages with your fingers, and the umber, give it breath with your mouth,
and it will&H1; discourse
most eloquent music, look you, these are the stops.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p:
But these cannot I command to&H4; any utterance of harmony, I
have not the skill.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Why look you now how unworthy a thing you make of
me, you would play upon&H4; me, you would seem to&H9; know my stops,
you would pluck out the heart of my mystery, you would sound me
from my lowest note to&H4; my compass, and there is much music excellent voice in&H4; this little organ, yet cannot you make it speak, 'sblood
do you think I am easier to&H9; be played on&H5; than a pipe, call me what instrument you will&H1;, though you fret me not, you cannot play upon&H4; me.
God bless you sir.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: My Lord, the Queen would speak with you, and presently.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Do you see yonder cloud that&H61; is almost in&H4; shape of a Camel?

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: By'th mass and it is like&H4; a Camel indeed.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Methinks it is like&H4; a Weasel.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.p: It is backed like&H4; a Weasel.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Or like&H4; a Whale.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: Very like&H4; a Whale.
Then I will&H1; come to&H4; my mother by&H5; and by&H5;,
They fool me to&H4; the top of my bent, I will&H1; come by&H5; and by&H5;,
Leave me friends.
I will&H1;, say so&H52;.
By&H5; and by&H5; is easily said,
It is now the very witching time of night,
When Churchyards yawn, and hell itself breaks out
Contagion to&H4; this world: now could I drink hot blood,
And do such business as the bitter day
Would quake to&H9; look on&H5; soft, now to&H4; my mother,
O heart lose not thy nature, let not ever
The soul of Nero enter this firm bosom,
Let me be cruel, not unnatural,
I will&H1; speak dagger to&H4; her&H6;, but use none,
My tongue and soul in&H4; this be hypocrites,
How in&H4; my words somever she be shent,
To&H9; give them seals never my soul consent.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I like&H1; him not, nor stands it safe with us&Hrp;,
To&H9; let his madness range, therefore prepare you,
I your commission will&H1; forth-with dispatch,
And he to&H4; England shall along with you,
The terms of our&Hrp; estate may not endure
Hazard so&H51; near us&Hrp; as doth hourly grow
Out of his brows.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.l: We&Htp; will&H1; ourselves provide,
Most holy and religious fear it is
To&H9; keep those many many bodies safe
That&H61; live and feed upon&H4; your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: The single and peculiar life is bound
With all the strength and armour of the mind
To&H9; keep itself from noyance, but much more
That&H62; spirit, upon&H4; whose weal depends and rests
The lives of many, the cease of Majesty
Dies not alone; but like&H4; a gulf doth draw
What is near it, with it, or it is a massy wheel
Fixed on&H4; the summit of the highest mount,
To&H4; whose huge spokes, ten thousand lesser things
Are mortised and adjoined, which&H61; when it falls,
Each small annexment petty consequence
Attends the boisterous rain, never alone
Did the King sigh, but a general groan.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Arm you I pray you to&H4; this speedy voyage,
For&H3; we&Hrp; will&H1; fetters put about this fear
Which&H61; now goes too free-footed.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: We&Htp; will&H1; haste us&Htp;,.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: My Lord, he is going to&H4; his mother's closet,
Behind the Arras I will&H1; convey myself.
To&H9; hear the process, I will&H1; warrant she will&H1; tax him home,
And as you said, and wisely was it said,
It is meet that&H3; some more audience than a mother,
Since nature makes them partial, should overhear
The speech of vantage; far you well my Liege,
I will&H1; call upon&H4; you ere you go to&H4; bed.
And tell you what I know.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Thanks dear my Lord.
O my offence is rank, it smells to&H4; heaven,
It hath the primal eldest curse upon&H4; it,
A brother's murther, pray can I not,
Though inclination be as sharp as will&H0;,
My stronger guilt defeats my strong intent,
And like&H4; a man to&H4; double business bound,
I stand in&H4; pause where I shall first begin,
And both neglect, what if this cursed hand
Were thicker than itself with brother's blood,
Is there not rain enough in&H4; the sweet Heavens
To&H9; wash it white as snow, whereto serves mercy
But to&H9; confront the visage of offence?
And what is in&H4; prayer but this two fold force,
To&H9; be forestalled ere we&Htp; come to&H9; fall,
Or pardon being down, then I will&H1; look up&H5;.
My fault is past, but o what form of prayer
Can serve my turn, forgive me my foul murther,
That&H62; cannot be since I am still possessed
Of those effects for&H4; which&H61; I did the murther;
My Crown, mine own ambition, and my Queen;
May one be pardoned and retain the offence?
In&H4; the corrupted currents of this world,
Offences gilded hand may show by&H4; justice,
And oft it is seen the wicked prize itself
Buys out the law, but it is not so&H52; above,
There is no&H2; shuffling, there the action lies
In&H4; his true nature, and we&Htp; ourselves compelled
Even to&H4; the teeth and forehead of our&Htp; faults
To&H9; give in&H4; evidence, what then, what rests,
Try what repentance can, what can it not,
Yet what can it, when one cannot repent?
O wretched state, o bosom black as death,
O limed soul, that&H61; struggling to&H9; be free,
Art more engaged; help Angels make assay,
Bow stubborn knees, and heart with strings of steal,
Be soft as sinews of the new borne babe,
All may be well.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Now might I do it, but now he is a-praying,
And now I will&H1; do it, and so&H52; he goes to&H4; heaven,
And so&H52; am I revenge, that&H62; would be scanned
A villain kills my father, and for&H4; that&H62;,
I his sole son, do this same villain send
To&H4; heaven.
Why, this is base and silly, not revenge,
He took my father grossly full of bread,
With all his crimes broad blown, as flush as May,
And how his audit stands who&H62; knows save heaven,
But in&H4; our&Htp; circumstance and course of thought,
It is heavy with him: and am I then revenged
To&H9; take him in&H4; the purging of his soul,
When he is fit and seasoned for&H4; his passage?
No&H7;.
Up&H5; sword, and know thou a more horrid hent,
When he is drunk, asleep, or in&H4; his rage,
Or in&H4; the incestuous pleasure of his bed,
At game a-swearing, or about some act
That&H61; has no&H2; relish of salvation in&H4; it,
Then trip him that&H3; his heels may kick at heaven,
And that&H3; his soul may be as damned and black
As hell whereto it goes; my mother stays,
This physic but prolongs thy sickly days.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: My words fly up&H5;, my thoughts remain below
Words without thoughts never to&H4; heaven go.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: He will&H1; come strait, look you lay home to&H4; him,
Tell him his pranks have been too broad to&H9; bear with,
And that&H3; your grace hath screened and stood between
Much heat and him, I will&H1; silence me even here,
Pray you be round.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: I will&H1; wait you, fear me not,
Withdraw, I hear him coming.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Now mother, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Hamlet, thou hast thy father much offended.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Mother, you have my father much offended.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Come, come, you answer with an idle tongue.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Go, go, you question with a wicked tongue.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Why how now Hamlet?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What is the matter now?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Have you forgot me?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No&H7; by&H4; the rood not so&H52;,
You are the Queen, your husband's brother's wife,
And would it were not so&H52;, you are my mother.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Nay, then I will&H1; set those to&H4; you that&H61; can speak.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Come, come, and sit you down, you shall not budge,
You go not till I set you up&H5; a glass
Where you may see the most part of you.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: What wilt thou do, thou wilt not murther me,
Help how.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: What how help.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How now, a Rat, dead for&H4; a Ducat, dead.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: O I am slain.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: O me, what hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay I know not, is it the King?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: O what a rash and bloody deed is this.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: A bloody deed, almost as bad, good mother
As kill a King, and marry with his brother.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: As kill a King.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Aye Lady, it was my word.
Thou wretched, rash, intruding fool farewell,
I took thee for&H4; thy better, take thy fortune,
Thou findest to&H9; be too busy is some danger,
Leave wringing of your hands, peace sit you down,
And let me wring your heart, for&H3; so&H52; I shall
If it be made of penetrable stuff,
If damned custom have not brazed it so&H51;,
That&H3; it be proof and bulwark against sense.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: What have I done, that&H3; thou darest wag thy tongue
In&H4; noise so&H51; rude against me?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Such an act
That&H61; blurs the grace and blush of modesty,
Calls vertue hypocrite, takes of the Rose
From the fair forehead of an innocent love,
And sets a blister there, makes marriage vows
As false as dicers' oaths, o such a deed,
As from the body of contraction plucks
The very soul, and sweet religion makes
A rhapsody of words; heaven's face does glow
Over this solidity and compound mass
With heated visage, as against the doom
Is thought sick at the act

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Ay me, what act?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: That&H61; roars so&H51; loud, and thunders in&H4; the Index,
Look here upon&H4; this Picture, and on&H4; this,
The counterfeit presentment of two brothers,
See what a grace was seated on&H4; this brow,
Hiperions curls, the front of Jove himself,
An eye like&H4; Mars, to&H9; threaten and command,
A station like&H4; the herald Mercury,
New lighted on&H4; a heaven, a kissing hill,
A combination, and a form indeed,
Where every God did seem to&H9; set his seal
To&H9; give the world assurance of a man,
This was your husband, look you now what follows,
Here is your husband like&H4; a mildewed ear,
Blasting his wholesome brother, have you eyes,
Could you on&H4; this fair mountain leave to&H9; feed,
And batten on&H4; this Moore; ha, have you eyes?
You cannot call it love, for&H3; at your age
The heyday in&H4; the blood is tame, it is humble,
And waits upon&H4; the judgment, and what judgment
Would step from this to&H4; this, sense sure you have
Else could you not have motion, but sure that&H62; sense
Is apoplexed, for&H3; madness would not err
Nor sense to&H4; ecstasy was never so&H51; thralled
But it reserved some quantity of choice
To&H9; serve in&H4; such a difference, what devil was it
That&H61; thus hath cozened you at hoodman blind;
Eyes without feeling, feeling without sight,
Ears without hands, or eyes, smelling sans all,
Or but a sickly part of one true sense
Could not so&H51; mope: o shame where is thy blush?
Rebellious hell,
If thou canst mutiny in&H4; a Matron's bones,
To&H4; flaming youth let vertue be as wax
And melt in&H4; her&H2; own fire, proclaim no&H2; shame
When the compulsive ardour gives the charge,
Since frost itself as actively doth burn,
And reason pardons will&H0;.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: O Hamlet speak no&H2; more,
Thou turnest my very eyes into my soul,
And there I see such black and grieved spots
As will&H1; leave there their tinct.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay but to&H9; live
In&H4; the rank sweat of an enseamed bed
Stewed in&H4; corruption, honeying, and making love
Over the nasty sty.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: O speak to&H4; me no&H2; more,
These words like&H4; daggers enter in&H4; my ears,
No&H2; more sweet Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: A murtherer and a villain,
A slave that&H61; is not twentieth part the kith
Of your precedent Lord, a vice of Kings,
A cut-purse of the Empire and the rule,
That&H61; from a shelf the precious Diadem stole
And put it in&H4; his pocket.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: No&H2; more.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: A King of shreds and patches,
Save me and hover over me with your wings
You heavenly guards: what would your gracious figure?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Alas he is mad.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Do you not come your tardy son to&H9; chide,
That&H61; lapsed in&H4; time and passion lets go by&H5;
The important acting of your dread command, o say.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Do not forget, this visitation
Is but to&H9; whet thy almost blunted purpose,
But look, amazement on&H4; thy mother sits,
O step between her&H6;, and her&H2; fighting soul,
Conceit in&H4; weakest bodies strongest works,
Speak to&H4; her&H6; Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How is it with you Lady?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Alas how is it with you?
That&H3; you do bend your eye on&H4; vacancy,
And with the incorporeal air do hold discourse,
Forth at your eyes your spirits wildly peep,
And as the sleeping soldiers in&H4; the alarm,
Your bedded hair like&H4; life in&H4; excrements
Start up&H5; and stand on&H4; end, o gentle son
Upon&H4; the heat and flame of thy distemper
Sprinkle cool patience, whereon do you look?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: On&H4; him, on&H4; him, look you how pale he glares,
His form and cause conjoined, preaching to&H4; stones
Would make them capable, do not look upon&H4; me,
Lest with this piteous action you convert
My stern effects, then what I have to&H9; do
Will&H1; want true colour, tears perchance for&H4; blood.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: To&H4; whom do you speak this?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Do you see nothing there?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Nothing at all, yet all that&H61; is I see.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nor did you nothing hear?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: No&H7; nothing but ourselves.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why look you there, look how it steals away,
My father in&H4; his habit as he lived,
Look where he goes, even now out at the portal.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: This is the very coinage of your brain,
This bodiless creation ecstasy is very cunning in&H5;.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: My pulse as yours doth temperately keep time,
And makes as healthful music, it is not madness
That&H61; I have uttered, bring me to&H4; the test,
And the matter will&H1; reword, which&H61; madness
Would gambol from, mother for&H4; love of grace,
Lay not that&H62; flattering unction to&H4; your soul
That&H3; not your trespass but my madness speaks,
It will&H1; but skin and film the ulcerous place
Whiles rank corruption mining all within
Infects unseen, confess yourself to&H4; heaven,
Repent what is past, avoid what is to&H9; come,
And do not spread the compost on&H4; the weeds
To&H9; make them rancour, forgive me this my vertue,
For&H3; in&H4; the fatness of these pursy times
Vertue itself of vice must pardon beg,
Yea curb and woo for&H4; leave to&H9; do him good.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: O Hamlet thou hast cleft my heart in&H4; twain.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O throw away the worser part of it,
And leave the purer with the other half,
Good night, but go not to&H4; my Uncle's bed,
Assume a vertue if you have it not,
That&H62; monster custom, who&H61; all sense doth eat
Of habits devil, is angel yet in&H4; this
That&H3; to&H4; the use of actions fair and good,
He likewise gives a frock or Livery
That&H61; aptly is put on&H5; to&H9; refrain night,
And that&H62; shall lend a kind of easiness
To&H4; the next abstinence, the next more easy:
For&H3; use almost can change the stamp of nature,
And either the devil, or throw him out
With wondrous potency: once more good night,
And when you are desirous to&H9; be blessed,
I will&H1; blessing beg of you, for&H3; this same Lord
I do repent; but heaven hath pleased it so&H52;
To&H9; punish me with this, and this with me,
That&H3; I must be their scourge and minister,
I will&H1; bestow him and will&H1; answer well
The death I gave him; so&H3; again good night
I must be cruel only to&H9; be kind,
This bad begins, and worse remains behind.
One word more good Lady.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Not this by&H4; no&H2; means that&H61; I bid you do,
Let the bloat King tempt you again to&H4; bed,
Pinch wanton on&H4; your cheek, call you his Mouse,
And let him for&H4; a pair of reechy kisses,
Or paddling in&H4; your neck with his damned fingers.
Make you to&H9; ravel all this matter out
That&H3; I essentially am not in&H4; madness,
But mad in&H4; craft, it were good you let him know,
For&H3; who&H62; that&H61; is but a Queen, fair, sober, wise,
Would from a paddock, from a bat, a gib,
Such dear concernings hide, who&H62; would do so&H52;,
No&H7;, in&H4; despite of sense and secrecy,
Unpeg the basket on&H4; the house's top,
Let the birds fly, and like&H4; the famous Ape,
To&H9; try conclusions in&H4; the basket creep,
And break your own neck down.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Be thou assured, if words be made of breath
And breath of life, I have no&H2; life to&H9; breathe
What thou hast said to&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I must to&H4; England, you know that&H62;.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Alack I had forgot.
It is so&H52; concluded on&H5;.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: There is letters sealed, and my two School-fellows,
Whom I will&H1; trust as I will&H1; Adders fanged,
They bear the mandate, they must sweep my way
And marshall me to&H4; knavery: let it work,
For&H3; it is the sport to&H9; have the engineer
Hoist with his own petard, and it shall go hard
But I will&H1; delve one yard below their mines,
And blow them at the Moon: o it is most sweet
When in&H4; one line two crafts directly meet,
This man shall set me packing,
I will&H1; lug the guts into the neighbour room;
Mother good night indeed, this Counselor
Is now most still, most secret, and most grave,
Who&H61; was in&H4; life a most foolish prating knave.
Come sir, to&H9; draw toward an end with you.
Good night mother.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: There is matter in&H4; these sighs, these profound heaves,
You must translate, it is fit we&Hrp; understand them,
Where is your son?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Bestow this place on&H4; us&Htp;, a little while.
Ah mine own Lord, what have I seen tonight?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: What Gertrard, how does Hamlet?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Mad as the sea and wind when both contend
Which&H61; is the mightier, in&H4; his lawless fit,
Behind the Arras hearing some thing stir,
Whips out his Rapier, cries a Rat, a Rat,
And in&H4; this brainish apprehension kills
The unseen good old man.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: O heavy deed!
It had been so&H52; with us&Hrp;, had we&Hrp; been there,
His liberty is full of threats to&H4; all,
To&H4; you yourself, to&H4; us&Hrp;, to&H4; everyone,
Alas, how shall this bloody deed be answered?
It will&H1; be laid to&H4; us&Hrp;, whose providence
Should have kept short, restrained, and out of haunt
This mad young man; but so&H51; much was our&Hrp; love,
We&Hrp; would not understand what was most fit,
But like&H4; the owner of a foul disease
To&H9; keep it from divulging, let it feed
Even on&H4; the pith of life: where is he gone?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: To&H9; draw apart the body he hath killed,
Over whom, his very madness like&H4; some ore
Among a mineral of metals base,
Shows itself pure, he weeps for&H4; what is done.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: O Gertrard, come away,
The sun no&H2; sooner shall the mountains touch,
But we&Htp; will&H1; ship him hence, and this vile deed
We&Hrp; must with all our&Hrp; Majesty and skill
Both countenance and excuse. Ho Guyldensterne,
Friends both, go join you with some further aid,
Hamlet in&H4; madness hath Polonius slain,
And from his mother's closet hath he dragged him,
Go seek him out, speak fair, and bring the body
Into the Chapel; I pray you haste in&H4; this,
Come Gertrard, we&Hrp; will&H1; call up&H5; our&Hrp; wisest friends,
And let them know both what we&Hrp; mean to&H9; do
And what is untimely done,
Whose whisper over the world's diameter,
As level as the Cannon to&H4; his blank,
Transports his poisoned shot, may miss our&Hrp; Name,
And hit the woundless air, o come away,
My soul is full of discord and dismay.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Safely stowed, but soft, what noise, who&H62; calls on&H4; Hamlet?
O here they come.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: What have you done my Lord with the dead body?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Compound it with dust whereto it is kin.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Tell us&Htp;, where it is that&H3; we&Htp; may take it thence,
And bear it to&H4; the Chapel.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Do not believe it.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Believe what.

sp.speaker: Ham.
Ros.
sp.p: Take you me for&H4; a sponge my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Aye sir, that&H61; soaks up&H5; the King's countenance, his rewards, his
authorities, but such Officers do the King best service in&H4; the end, he
keeps them like&H4; an apple in&H4; the corner of his jaw, first mouthed to&H9; be
last swallowed, when he needs what you have gleaned, it is but squeezing you, and sponge you shall be dry again.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I understand you not my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I am glad of it, a knavish speech sleeps in&H4; a foolish ear.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: My Lord, you must tell us&Htp;, where the body is, and go with us&Htp;, to&H4; the King.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: The body is with the King, but the King is not with the body. The King is a thing.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.p: A thing my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Of nothing, bring me to&H4; him.

stage.l: Enter King, and two or three.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I have sent to&H9; seek him, and to&H9; find the body,
How dangerous is it that&H3; this man goes loose,
Yet must not we&Hrp; put the strong Law on&H4; him,
he is loved of the distracted multitude,
Who&H61; like&H1; not in&H4; their judgment, but their eyes,
And where it is so&H52;, the offenders scourge is weighed
But never the offence: to&H9; bear all smooth and even,
This sudden sending him away must seem
Deliberate pause, diseases desperate grown,
By&H4; desperate appliance are relieved
Or not at all.

stage.l: Enter Rosencraus and all the rest.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: How now, what hath befallen?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Where the dead body is bestowed my Lord
We&Htp; cannot get from him.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: But where is he?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Without my lord, guarded to&H9; know your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Bring him before us&Hrp;.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: How, bring in&H5; the Lord.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Now Hamlet, where is Polonius?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: At supper.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: At supper, where.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Not where he eats, but where he is eaten, a certain convocation of politic worms are even at him: your worm is your only
Emperor for&H4; diet, we&Htp; fat all creatures else to&H9; fat us&Htp;, and we&Htp; fat ourselves
for&H4; maggots, your fat King and your lean beggar is but variable service, two dishes but to&H4; one table, that&H62; is the end.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Alas, alas.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
A man may fish with the worm that&H61; hath eat of a King, and
eat of the fish that&H61; hath fed of that&H62; worm.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: What dost thou mean by&H4; this?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Nothing but to&H9; show you how a King may go a progress
through the guts of a beggar.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Where is Polonius?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
In&H4; heaven, send thither to&H9; see, if your messenger find him
not there, seek him in&H4; the other place yourself, but if indeed you find
him not within this month, you shall nose him as you go up&H5; the
stayres into the Lobby.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Go seek him there.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: He will&H1; stay till you come.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Hamlet this deed for&H4; thine especial safety
Which&H61; we&Hrp; do tender, as we&Hrp; dearly grieve
For&H4; that&H62; which&H61; thou hast done, must send thee hence.
Therefore prepare thyself,
The Bark is ready, and the wind at help,
The associates tend, and everything is bent
For&H4; England.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: For&H4; England.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Aye Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: So&H52; is it if thou knewest our&Hrp; purposes.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I see a Cherub that&H61; sees them, but come for&H4; England,
Farewell dear Mother.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Thy loving Father Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
My mother, Father and Mother is man and wife,
Man and wife is one flesh, so&H3; my mother:
Come for&H4; England.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Follow him at foot,
Tempt him with speed aboard,
Delay it not, I will&H1; have him hence tonight.
Away, for&H3; everything is sealed and done
That&H61; else leans on&H4; the affair, pray you make haste,
And England, if my love thou holdest at aught,
As my great power thereof may give thee sense,
Since yet thy Cicatrice looks raw and red,
After the Danish sword, and thy free awe
Pays homage to&H4; us&Hrp;,, thou mayst not coldly set
Our&Hrp; sovereign process, which&H61; imports at full
By&H4; Letters congruing to&H4; that&H62; effect
The present death of Hamlet, do it England,
For&H3; like&H4; the Hectic in&H4; my blood he rages,
And thou must cure me; till I know it is done,
However my haps, my joys will&H1; never begin.

stage.l: Enter Fortinbrasse with his Army ouer the stage.

sp.speaker: Fortin.
sp.l: Go Captain, from me greet the Danish King,
Tell him, that&H3; by&H4; his license Fortinbrasse
Craves the conveyance of a promised march
Over his kingdom, you know the rendezvous,
If that&H3; his Majesty would aught with us&Hrp;,,
We&Hrp; shall express our&Hrp; duty in&H4; his eye,
And let him know so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I will&H1; do it my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fortin.
sp.l: Go softly on&H5;.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Good sir whose powers are these?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: They are of Norway sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How purposed sir I pray you?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Against some part of Poland.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Who&H62; commands them sir?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: The Nephew to&H4; old Norway, Fortenbrasse.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Goes it against the main of Poland sir,
Or for&H4; some frontier?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Truly to&H9; speak, and with no&H2; addition,
We&Htp; go to&H9; gain a little patch of ground
That&H61; hath in&H4; it no&H2; profit but the name
To&H9; pay five ducats, five I would not farm it;
Nor will&H1; it yield to&H4; Norway or the Pole
A rancour rate, should it be sold in&H4; fee.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why then the Pollacke never will&H1; defend it.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Yes, it is already garrisoned.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Two thousand souls, and twenty thousand ducats
Will&H1; not debate the question of this straw,
This is the Imposthume of much wealth and peace,
That&H61; inward breaks, and shows no&H2; cause without
Why the man dies. I humbly thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: God buy you sir.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Will&H1; it please you go my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I will&H1; be with you straight, go a little before.
How all occasions do inform against me,
And spur my dull revenge. What is a man
If his chief good and market of his time
Be but to&H9; sleep and feed, a beast, no&H2; more:
Sure he that&H61; made us&Htp;, with such large discourse
Looking before and after, gave us&Htp;, not
That&H62; capability and god-like reason
To&H9; fust in&H4; us&Htp;, unused, now whether it be
Bestial oblivion, or some craven scruple
Of thinking too precisely on&H4; the event,
A thought which&H61; quartered hath but one part wisdom,
And ever three parts coward, I do not know
Why yet I live to&H9; say this thing is to&H9; do,
Sith I have cause, and will&H0;, and strength, and means
To&H9; do it; examples gross as earth exhort me,
Witness this Army of such mass and charge,
Led by&H4; a delicate and tender Prince,
Whose spirit with divine ambition puffed,
Makes mouths at the invisible event,
Exposing what is mortal, and unsure,
To&H4; all that&H61; fortune, death, and danger dare,
Even for&H4; an Eggshell. Rightly to&H9; be great,
Is not to&H9; stir without great argument,
But greatly to&H9; find quarrel in&H4; a straw
When honour is at the stake, how stand I then
That&H61; have a father killed, a mother stained,
Excitements of my reason, and my blood,
And let all sleep, while to&H4; my shame I see
The imminent death of twenty thousand men,
That&H61; for&H4; a fantasy and trick of fame
Go to&H4; their graves like&H4; beds, fight for&H4; a plot
Whereon the numbers cannot try the cause,
Which&H61; is not tomb enough and continent
To&H9; hide the slain, o from this time forth,
My thoughts be bloody, or be nothing worth.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: I will&H1; not speak with her&H6;.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: She is importunate,
Indeed distract, her&H2; mood will&H1; needs be pitied.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: What would she have?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: She speaks much of her&H2; father, says she hears
There is tricks in&H4; the world, and hems, and beats her&H2; heart,
Spurns enviously at straws, speaks things in&H4; doubt
That&H61; carry but half sense, her&H2; speech is nothing,
Yet the unshaped use of it doth move
The hearers to&H4; collection, they yawn at it,
And botch the words up&H5; fit to&H4; their own thoughts,
Which&H61; as her&H2; winks, and nods, and gestures yield them,
Indeed would make one think there might be thought
Though nothing sure, yet much unhappily.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: It were good she were spoken with, for&H3; she may strew
Dangerous conjectures in&H4; ill breeding minds,
Let her&H6; come in&H5;.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: To&H4; my sick soul, as sin's true nature is,
Each toy seems prologue to&H4; some great amiss,
So&H51; full of artless jealousy is guilt,
It spills itself, in&H4; fearing to&H9; be spilt.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: Where is the beauteous Majesty of Denmarke?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: How now Ophelia?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: How should I your true love know from another one,
By&H4; his cockle hat and staff, and his Sandal shoon.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Alas sweet Lady, what imports this song?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: Say you, nay pray you mark,
He is dead and gone Lady, he is dead and gone,
At his head a grass-green turf, at his heels a stone.
O ho.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Nay but Ophelia.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p:
Pray you mark.
White his shroud as the mountain snow.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Alas look here my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: Larded all with sweet flowers,
Which&H61; beweeped to&H4; the ground did not go
With true love showers.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: How do you pretty Lady?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p:
Well good dild you, they say the Owl was a Baker's daughter, Lord we&Htp; know what we&Htp; are, but know not what we&Htp; may be.
God be at your table.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Conceit upon&H4; her&H2; Father.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: Pray let us&Htp; have no&H2; words of this, but when they ask you
what it means, say you this.
Tomorrow is Saint Valentines day,
All in&H4; the morning betime,
And I a maid at your window
To&H9; be your Valentine.
Then up&H5; he rose, and donned his clothes, and dupped the chamber door,
Let in&H5; the maid, that&H61; out a maid, never departed more.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Pretty Ophelia.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: Indeed without an oath I will&H1; make an end on&H4; it,
By&H4; gis and by&H4; Saint Charity,
alack and fie for&H4; shame,
Young men will&H1; do it if they come to&H4; it,
by&H4; Cock they are too blame.
Quoth she, Before you tumbled me, you promised me to&H9; wed,
(He answers.) So&H52; would I have done by&H4; yonder sun
And thou hadst not come to&H4; my bed.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: How long hath she been thus?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p:
I hope all will&H1; be well, we&Htp; must be patient, but I cannot choose
but weep to&H9; think they would lay him in&H4; the cold ground, my brother
shall know of it, and so&H3; I thank you for&H4; your good counsel. Come
my Coach, God night Ladies, god night.
Sweet Ladies good night, good night.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Follow her&H6; close, give her&H6; good watch I pray you.
O this is the poison of deep grief, it springs all from her&H2; Father's
death, and now behold, o Gertrard, Gertrard,
When sorrows come, they come not single spies,
But in&H4; battalions: first her&H2; Father slain,
Next, your son gone, and he most violent Author
Of his own just remove, the people muddied
Thick and unwholesome in&H4; thoughts, and whispers
For&H4; good Polonius death: and we&Hrp; have done but greenly
In&H4; hugger mugger to&H9; inter him: poor Ophelia
Divided from herself, and her&H2; fair judgment,
Without the which&H61; we&Htp; are pictures, or mere beasts,
Last, and as much containing as all these,
Her&H2; brother is in&H4; secret come from France,
Feeds on&H4; this wonder, keeps himself in&H4; clouds,
And wants not buzzers to&H9; infect his ear
With pestilent speeches of his father's death,
Wherein necessity of matter beggared,
Will&H1; nothing stick our&Hrp; person to&H9; arraign
In&H4; ear and ear: o my dear Gertrard, this
Like&H4; to&H4; a murdering piece in&H4; many places
Gives me superfluous death.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Attend, where is my Swissers, let them guard the door,
What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: Save yourself my Lord.
The Ocean over-peering of his list
Eats not the flats with more impetuous haste
Than young Laertes in&H4; a riotous head
Overbears your Officers: the rabble call him Lord,
And as the world were now but to&H9; begin,
Antiquity forgot, custom not known,
The ratifiers and props of every word,
The cry choose we&Htp;, Laertes shall be King,
Caps, hands, and tongues applaud it to&H4; the clouds,
Laertes shall be King, Laertes King.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: How cheerfully on&H4; the false trail they cry.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: O this is counter you false Danish dogs.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: The doors are broke.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Where is this King? sirs stand you all without.

sp.speaker: Supp.
sp.l: No&H7; let us&Htp; come in&H5;.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I pray you give me leave.

sp.speaker: Supp.
sp.l: We&Htp; will&H1;, we&Htp; will&H1;.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I thank you, keep the door, o thou vile King,
Give me my father.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Calmly good Laertes.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: That&H62; drop of blood that&H61; is. calm proclaims me Bastard,
Cries cuckold to&H4; my father, brands the Harlot
Even here between the chaste unsmirched brow
Of my true mother.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: What is the cause Laertes
That&H3; thy rebellion looks so&H51; giant-like?
Let him go Gertrard, do not fear our&Hrp; person,
There is such divinity doth hedge a King,
That&H3; treason can but peep to&H4; what it would,
Acts little of his will&H0;, tell me Laertes
Why thou art thus incensed, let him go Gertrard.
Speak man.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Where is my father?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Dead.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: But not by&H4; him.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Let him demand his fill.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: How came he dead, I will&H1; not be juggled with,
To&H4; hell allegiance, vows to&H4; the blackest devil,
Conscience and grace, to&H4; the profoundest pit
I dare damnation, to&H4; this point I stand,
That&H3; both the worlds I give to&H4; negligence,
Let come what comes, only I will&H1; be revenged
Most thoroughly for&H4; my father.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Who&H62; shall stay you?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: My will&H0;, not all the worlds:
And for&H4; my means I will&H1; husband them so&H51; well,
They shall go far with little.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Good Laertes, if you desire to&H9; know the certainty
Of your dear Father, is it writ in&H4; your revenge,
That&H3; sweepstake, you will&H1; draw both friend and foe
Winner and looser.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: None but his enemies,

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Will&H1; you know them then?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: To&H4; his good friends thus wide I will&H1; ope my arms,
And like&H4; the kind life-rendering Pelican,
Repast them with my blood.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Why now you speak
Like&H4; a good child, and a true Gentleman.
That&H3; I am guiltless of your father's death,
And am most sensibly in&H4; grief for&H4; it,
It shall as level to&H4; your judgment appear
As day does to&H4; your eye.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Let her&H6; come in&H5;.
How now, what noise is that&H62;?
O heat, dry up&H5; my brains, tears seven times salt
Burn out the sense and vertue of mine eye,
By&H4; heaven thy madness shall be paid with weight
Till our&Htp; scale turn the beam. O Rose of May,
Dear maid, kind sister, sweet Ophelia,
O heavens, is it possible a young maid's wits
Should be as mortal as a poor man's life.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: They bore him barefaced on&H4; the Bier,
And in&H4; his grave rained many a tear,
Fare you well my Dove.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Hadst thou thy wits, and didst persuade revenge
It could not move thus.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p:
You must sing a-down a-down,
And you call him a-down-a. O how the wheel becomes it,
It is the false Steward that&H61; stole his Master's daughter.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: This nothing is more than matter.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p: There is Rosemary, that&H62; is. for&H4; remembrance, pray you love remember, and there is Pansies, that&H62; is. for&H4; thoughts.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: A document in&H4; madness, thoughts and remembrance fitted.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p:
There is Fennel for&H4; you, and Columbines, there is Rue for&H4;
you, and here is some for&H4; me, we&Htp; may call it herb of Grace a-Sundays,
you may wear your Rue with a difference, there is a Daisy, I would
give you some Violets, but they withered all when my Father dyed,
they say he made a good end.
For&H3; bonny sweet Robin is all my joy.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Thought and afflictions, passion, hell itself
She turns to&H4; favour and to&H4; prettiness.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: And will&H1; he not come again,
And will&H1; he not come again,
No&H7;, no&H7;, he is dead, go to&H4; thy death bed,
He never will&H1; come again.
His beard was as white as snow,
Flaxen was his poll,
He is gone, he is gone, and we&Htp; cast away moan,
God a mercy on&H4; his soul,
and of all Christians' souls,
God buy you.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Do you this o God.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Laertes, I must commune with your grief,
Or you deny me right, go but apart,
Make choice of whom your wisest friends you will&H1;,
And they shall hear and judge twixt you and me,
If by&H4; direct, or by&H4; collateral hand
They find us&Hrp;, touched, we&Hrp; will&H1; our&Hrp; kingdom give,
Our&Hrp; crown, our&Hrp; life, and all that&H61; we&Hrp; call ours&Hrp;
To&H4; you in&H4; satisfaction; but if not,
Be you content to&H9; lend your patience to&H4; us&Hrp;,,
And we&Hrp; shall jointly labour with your soul
To&H9; give it due content.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Let this be so&H52;.
His means of death, his obscure funeral,
No&H2; trophy sword, nor hatchment over his bones,
No&H2; noble right, nor formal ostentation,
Cry to&H9; be heard as it were from heaven to&H4; earth,
That&H3; I must call it in&H4; question.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: So&H52; you shall,
And where the offence is, let the great axe fall.
I pray you go with me.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: What are they that&H61; would speak with me?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Sea-faring men sir, they say they have Letters for&H4; you.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Let them come in&H5;.
I do not know from what part of the world
I should be greeted. If not from Lord Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: God bless you sir.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Let him bless thee too.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p:
He shall sir and please him, there is a Letter for&H4; you sir, it came
from the Ambassador that&H61; was bound for&H4; England, if your name be Horatio, as I am let to&H9; know it is.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p:
Horatio, when thou shalt have over-looked this, give these fellows some means to&H4; the King, they have Letters for&H4; him: Ere we&Htp;
were two days old at Sea, a Pirate of very warlike appointment gave
us&Htp;, chase, finding ourselves too slow of sail, we&Htp; put on&H4; a compelled
valour, and in&H4; the grapple I boarded them, on&H4; the instant they got
clear of our&Htp; ship, so&H52; I alone became their prisoner, they have dealt
with me like&H4; thieves of mercy, but they knew what they did, I am to&H9;
do a turn for&H4; them, let the King have the Letters I have sent, and
repair thou to&H4; me with as much speed as thou wouldst fly death,
I have words to&H9; speak in&H4; thine ear will&H1; make thee dumb, yet are
they much too light for&H4; the board of the matter, these good fellows
will&H1; bring thee where I am, Rosencraus and Guyldensterne hold their
course for&H4; England, of them I have much to&H9; tell thee, farewell.
So&H3; that&H3; thou knowest thine Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Come I will&H1; you way for&H4; these your letters,
And do it the speedier that&H3; you may direct me
To&H4; him from whom you brought them.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Now must your conscience my acquittance seal,
And you must put me in&H4; your heart for&H4; friend,
Sith you have heard and with a knowing ear,
That&H3; he which&H61; hath your noble father slain
Pursued my life.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: It well appears: but tell me
Why you proceed not against these feats
So&H51; criminal and so&H51; capital in&H4; nature,
As by&H4; your safety, greatness, wisdom, all things else
You mainly were stirred up&H5;.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: O for&H4; two special reasons
Which&H61; may to&H4; you perhaps seem much unsinewed,
But yet to&H4; me they are strong, the Queen his mother
Lives almost by&H4; his looks, and for&H4; myself.,
My vertue or my plague, be it either which&H61;,
She is so&H51; concliue to&H4; my life and soul,
That&H3; as the star moves not but in&H4; his sphere
I could not but by&H4; her&H6;, the other motive,
Why to&H4; a public count I might not go,
Is the great love the general gender bear him,
Who&H61; dipping all his faults in&H4; their affection,
Work like&H4; the spring that&H61; turneth wood to&H4; stone,
Convert his Gives to&H4; graces, so&H3; that&H3; my arrows
Too slightly timbered for&H4; so&H51; loved Armed,
Would have reverted to&H4; my bow again,
But not where I have aimed them.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: And so&H3; have I a noble father lost,
A sister driven into desperate terms,
Whose worth, if praises may go back again
Stood challenger on&H4; mount of all the age
For&H4; her&H2; perfections, but my revenge will&H1; come.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Break not your sleeps for&H4; that&H62;, you must not think
That&H3; we&Hrp; are made of stuff so&H51; flat and dull,
That&H3; we&Hrp; can let our&Hrp; beard be shook with danger,
And think it pastime, you shortly shall hear more,
I loved your father, and we&Hrp; love ourself,
And that&H62; I hope will&H1; teach you to&H9; imagine.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: These to&H4; your Majesty, this to&H4; the Queen.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: From Hamlet, who&H62; brought them?

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: Sailors my Lord they say, I saw them not,
They were given me by&H4; Claudio, he received them
Of him that&H61; brought them.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Laertes you shall hear them: leave us&Hrp;.
sp.p:
High and mighty, you shall know I am set naked on&H4; your kingdom,
tomorrow shall I beg leave to&H9; see your kingly eyes, when I shall first
asking you pardon, there-unto recount the occasion of my sudden
return.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: What should this mean, are all the rest come back,
Or is it some abuse, and no&H2; such thing?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Know you the hand?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: It is Hamlets character. Naked,
And in&H4; a postscript here he says alone,
Can you devise me?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I am lost in&H4; it my Lord, but let him come,
It warms the very sickness in&H4; my heart
That&H3; I live and tell him to&H4; his teeth
Thus didst thou.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: If it be so&H52; Laertes,
As how should it be so&H52;, how otherwise,
Will&H1; you be ruled by&H4; me?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Aye my Lord, so&H3; you will&H1; not ore-rule me to&H4; a peace.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: To&H4; thine own peace, if he be now returned
As the King at his voyage, and that&H3; he means
No&H2; more to&H9; undertake it, I will&H1; work him
To&H4; an exploit, now ripe in&H4; my devise,
Under the which&H61; he shall not choose but fall:
And for&H4; his death no&H2; wind of blame shall breathe,
But even his Mother shall uncharge the practise,
And call it accident.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: My Lord I will&H1; be ruled,
The rather if you could devise it so&H52;
That&H3; I might be the organ.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: It falls right,
You have been talked of since your travail much,
And that&H62; in&H4; Hamlets hearing, for&H4; a quality
Wherein they say you shine, your sum of parts
Did not together pluck such envy from him
As did that&H62; one, and that&H62; in&H4; my regard
Of the unworthiest siege.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: What part is that&H62; my Lord?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: A very ribband in&H4; the cap of youth,
Yet needful too, for&H3; youth no&H2; less becomes
The light and careless livery that&H61; it wears
Than settled age, his sables, and his weeds
Importing health and graveness; two months since
Here was a gentleman of Normandy,
I have seen myself, and served against the French,
And they can well on&H4; horseback, but this gallant
Had witch-craft in&H4; it, he grew unto his seat,
And to&H4; such wondrous doing brought his horse,
As had he been incorpsed, and demi natured
With the brave beast, so&H51; far he topped methought,
That&H3; I in&H4; forgery of shapes and tricks
Come short of what he did.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: A Norman was it ?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: A Norman.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Upon&H4; my life Lamord.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: The very same.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I know him well, he is the brooch indeed
And Gem of all the Nation.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: He made confession of you,
And gave you such a masterly report
For&H4; art and exercise in&H4; your defence,
And for&H4; your Rapier most especial,
That&H3; he cried out it would be a sight indeed
If one could match you; the Scrimers of their nation
He swore had neither motion, guard, nor eye,
If you opposed them; sir this report of his
Did Hamlet so&H51; envenom with his envy,
That&H3; he could nothing do but wish and beg
Your sudden coming over to&H9; play with you.
Now out of this.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: What out of this my Lord?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Laertes was your father dear to&H4; you?
Or are you like&H4; the painting of a sorrow,
A face without a heart?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Why ask you this?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Not that&H3; I think you did not love your father,
But that&H3; I know, love is begun by&H4; time,
And that&H3; I see in&H4; passages of proof,
Time qualifies the spark and fire of it,
There lives within the very flame of love
A kind of week or snuff that&H61; will&H1; abate it,
And nothing is at a like&H2; goodness still,
For&H3; goodness growing to&H4; a pleurisy,
Dies in&H4; his own too much, that&H3; we&Htp; would do
We&Htp; should do when we&Htp; would: for&H3; this would changes,
And hath abatements and delays as many,
As there are tongues, are hands, are accidents,
And then this should is like&H4; a spendthrift's sigh,
That&H61; hurts by&H4; easing; but to&H4; the quick of the ulcer,
Hamlet comes back, what would you undertake
To&H9; show yourself indeed your father's son
More than in&H4; words?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: To&H9; cut his throat in&H4; the Church.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: No&H2; place indeed should murther sanctuarise,
Revenge should have no&H2; bounds: but good Laertes
Will&H1; you do this, keep close within your chamber,
Hamlet returned, shall know you are come home,
We&Hrp; will&H1; put on&H4; those shall praise your excellence,
And set a double varnish on&H4; the fame
The french man gave you, bring you in&H4; fine together
And wager over your heads; he being remiss,
Most generous, and free from all contriving,
Will&H1; not peruse the foils, so&H3; that&H3; with ease,
Or with a little shuffling, you may choose
A sword unbated, and in&H4; a pace of practise
Requite him for&H4; your Father.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I will&H1; do it,
And for&H4; purpose, I will&H1; anoint my sword.
I bought an unction of a Mountebank
So&H51; mortal, that&H3; but dip a knife in&H4; it,
Where it draws blood, no&H2; Cataplasm so&H51; rare,
Collected from all simples that&H61; have vertue
Under the Moon, can save the thing from death
That&H61; is but scratched withal, I will&H1; touch my point
With this contagion, that&H3; if I gall him slightly, it may be death.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Let us&Htp; further think of this.
Weigh what convenience both of time and means
May fit us&Htp;, to&H4; our&Htp; shape if this should fail,
And that&H3; our&Htp; drift look through our&Htp; bad performance,
It were better not assayed, therefore this project,
Should have a back or second that&H61; might hold
If this did blast in&H4; proof; soft let me see,
We&Htp; will&H1; make a solemn wager on&H4; your cunnings,
I have it, when in&H4; your motion you are hot and dry,
As make your bouts more violent to&H4; that&H62; end,
And that&H3; he calls for&H4; drink, I will&H1; have prepared him
A Chalice for&H4; the nonce, whereon but sipping,
If he by&H4; chance escape your venomed stuck,
Our&Htp; purpose may hold there; but stay, what noise?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: One woe doth tread upon&H4; another's heel,
So&H51; fast they follow; your Sister is drowned Laertes.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Drowned, o where?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: There is a Willow grows askant the Brooke
That&H61; shows his hoary leaves in&H4; the glassy stream,
Therewith fantastic garlands did she make
Of Crowflowers, Nettles, Daises, and long Purples
That&H61; liberal Shepherds give a grosser name,
But our&Htp; cull-cold maids do dead men's fingers call them.
There on&H4; the pendant boughs her&H2; coronet weeds
Clambering to&H9; hang, an envious sliver broke,
When down her&H2; weedy trophies and herself
Fell in&H4; the weeping Brooke, her&H2; clothes spread wide,
And Mermaid-like awhile they bore her&H6; up&H5;,
Which&H61; time she chanted snatches of old lauds,
As one incapable of her&H2; own distress,
Or like&H4; a creature native and endowed
