Unto that&H62; element, but long it could not be
Till that&H3; her&H2; garments heavy with their drink,
Pulled the poor wretch from her&H2; melodious lay
To&H4; muddy death.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Alas, then she is drowned.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Drowned, drowned.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Too much of water hast thou poor Ophelia,
And therefore I forbid my tears; but yet
It is our&Htp; trick, nature her&H2; custom holds,
Let shame say what it will&H1;, when these are gone,
The woman will&H1; be out. Adieu my Lord,
I have a speech afire that&H61; fain would blaze,
But that&H3; this folly drowns it.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Let us&Htp; follow Gertrard,
How much I had to&H9; do to&H9; calm his rage,
Now fear I this will&H1; give it start again,
Therefore let us&Htp; follow.

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p:
Is she to&H9; be buried in&H4; Christian burial, when she wilfully
seeks her&H2; own salvation?

sp.speaker: Clowne2
sp.p: I tell thee she is, therefore make her&H2; grave straight, the coroner hath sate on&H4; her&H6;, and finds it Christian burial.

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p:
How can that&H62; be, unless she drowned herself in&H4; her&H2; own
defence.

sp.speaker: Clowne2
sp.p: Why it is found so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p:
It must be so&H52; offended, it cannot be else, for&H3; here lies the
point, if I drown myself. wittingly, it argues an act, and an act hath
three branches, it is to&H9; act, to&H9; do, to&H9; perform, or all; she drowned herself
wittingly.

sp.speaker: Clowne2
sp.p: Nay, but hear you good man deliver.

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p:
Give me leave, here lies the water, good, here stands the
man, good, if the man go to&H4; this water and drown himself, it is will&H1;
he, nill he, he goes, mark you that&H62;, but if the water come to&H4; him, and
drown him, he drowns not himself, argal, he that&H61; is not guilty of
his own death, shortens not his own life.

sp.speaker: Clowne2
sp.l: But is this law?

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.l: Aye marry is it, Coroner's quest law.

sp.speaker: Clowne2
sp.l: Will&H1; you have the truth on&H4; it, if this had not been a gentlewoman, she should have been buried out a christian burial.

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p:
Why there thou sayst, and the more pity that&H3; great folk
should have countenance in&H4; this world to&H9; drown or hang themselves,
more than their even Christen: Come my spade, there is no&H2; ancient gentlemen but Gardeners, Ditchers, and Grave-makers, they hold
up&H5; Adams profession.

sp.speaker: Clowne2
sp.p: Was he a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p:
He was the first that&H61; ever bore Arms.
I will&H1; put another question to&H4; thee, if thou answerest me not to&H4; the purpose, confess thyself.

sp.speaker: Clowne2
sp.p: Go to&H5;.

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p:
What is he that&H61; builds stronger than either the Mason, the
Shipwright, or the Carpenter.

sp.speaker: Clowne2
sp.p: The gallows maker, for&H3; that&H62; out-lives a thousand tenants.

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p:
I like&H1; thy wit well in&H4; good faith, the gallows does well,
but howe does it well? It does well to&H4; those that&H61; do ill, now thou
dost ill to&H9; say the gallows is built stronger than the Church, argal,
the gallows may do well to&H4; thee. To&H4; it again, come.

sp.speaker: Clowne2
sp.p: Who&H62; builds stronger than a Mason, a Shipwright, or a Carpenter.

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p: Aye, tell me that&H62; and unyoke.

sp.speaker: Clowne2
sp.p: Marry now I can tell.

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p: To&H4; it.

sp.speaker: Clowne2
sp.p: Mass I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p:
Cudgel thy brains no&H2; more about it, for&H3; your dull ass will&H1;
not mend his pace with beating, and when you are asked this question
next, say a grave-maker, the houses he makes lasts till Doomsday.
Go get thee in&H5;, and fetch me a soup of liquor.
In&H4; youth when I did love did love,

Me thought it was very sweet
To&H9; contract of the time for&H4; a my behove,
O methought there a was nothing a meet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Has this fellow no&H2; feeling of his business? he sings in&H4; grave-making.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Custom hath made it in&H4; him a property of easiness.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: It is even so&H52;, the hand of little employment hath the daintier sense

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p: But age with his stealing steppes

hath clawed me in&H4; his clutch,
And hath shipped me into the land,
as if I had never been such.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
That&H62; skull had a tongue in&H4; it, and could sing once, how the
knave jowls it to&H4; the ground, as if it were Caines oppone, that&H61; did the
first murder, this might be the pate of a politician, which&H61; this ass now
ore-reaches; one that&H61; would circumvent God, might it not?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: It might my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
Hora.
sp.p: Aye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Why even so&H3;, and now my Lady worm is Chapless, and knocked
about the mazard with a Sexton's spade; here is fine revolution if
we&Htp; had the trick to&H9; see it, did these bones cost no&H2; more the breeding,
but to&H9; play at loggets with them: mine ache to&H9; think on&H4; it.

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p: A pickax and a spade a spade,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
There is another, why may not that&H62; be the skull of a Lawyer,
where be his quiddities now, his quillities, his cases, his tenures, and his
tricks? why does he suffer this mad knave now to&H9; knock him about the sconce with a dirty shovel, and will&H1; not tell him of his action of battery, hum, this fellow
might be in&H4; his time a great buyer of
Land, with his Statutes, his recognisances, his fines, his double vouchers, his recoveries, to&H9; have his fine pate full of fine dirt, will&H1; vouchers vouch him no&H2; more of his
purchases and doubles than the length
and breadth of a pair of Indentures? The very conveyances of his
Lands will&H1; scarcely lie in&H4; this box, and must the inheritor himself have
no&H2; more, ha.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Not a jot more my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Is not Parchment made of sheep-skins?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Aye my Lord, and of Calves' skins too.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
They are Sheep and Calves which&H61; seek out assurance in&H4;
that&H62;, I will&H1; speak to&H4; this fellow. Whose grave is this sirrah?

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p: Mine sir, or a pit of clay for&H4; to&H9; be made.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I think it be thine indeed, for&H3; thou liest in&H4; it.

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p:
You lie out on&H4; it sir, and therefore it is not yours; for&H4; my part I
do not lie in&H4; it, yet it is mine.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Thou dost lie in&H4; it to&H9; be in&H4; it and say it is thine, it is for&H4; the dead,
not for&H4; the quick, therefore thou liest.

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p: It is a quick lie sir, it will&H1; away again from me to&H4; you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What man dost thou dig it for&H5;?

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p: For&H4; no&H2; man sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What woman then?

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p: For&H4; none neither.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Who&H62; is to&H9; be buried in&H4; it?

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p: One that&H61; was a woman sir, but rest her&H2; soul she is dead.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
How absolute the knave is, we&Htp; must speak by&H4; the card, or
equivocation will&H1; undo us&Htp;. By&H4; the Lord Horatio, this three years I
have took note of it, the age is grown so&H51; picked, that&H3; the toe of the
peasant comes so&H51; near the heel of the Courtier he galls his kibe. How
long hast thou been Grave-maker?

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p:
Of the days in&H4; the year I came to&H4; it that&H62; day that&H61; our&Htp; last king
Hamlet overcame Fortenbrasse.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: How long is that&H62; since?

sp.speaker: Clowne1
Ham.
sp.p: Aye marry, why was he sent into England?

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p:
Why because he was mad: he shall recover his wits there, or if
he do not, it is no&H2; great matter there.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p: It will&H1; not be seen in&H4; him there, there the men are as mad as he.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: How came he mad?

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p: Very strangely they say.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: How strangely?

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p: Faith even with loosing his wits.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Upon&H4; what ground?

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p:
Why here in&H4; Denmarke: I have been Sexton here man
and boy thirty years.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: How long will&H1; a man lie in&H4; the earth ere he rot?

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p:
Faith if he be not rotten before he die, as we&Htp; have many pocky corses, that&H61; will&H1; scarce hold the laying in&H5;, he will&H1; last you some eight
year, or nine year. A Tanner will&H1; last you nine year.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Why he more than another?

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p:
Why sir, his hide is so&H51; tanned with his trade, that&H3; he will&H1; keep
out water a great while; and your water is a sore decayer of your whoreson dead body, here is a scull now hath lain you in&H4; the earth twenty-three years.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Whose was it?

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p: A whoreson mad fellows it was, whose do you think it was?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Nay I know not.

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p:
A pestilence on&H4; him for&H4; a mad rogue, he poured a flagon of
Rhenish on&H4; my head once; this same skull sir, was sir Yoricks skull, the
King's Jester.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: This?

sp.speaker: Clowne1
sp.p: Even that&H62;.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Alas poor Yoricke, I knew him Horatio, a fellow of infinite
jest, of most excellent fancy, he hath bore me on&H4; his back a thousand times, and now how abhorred in&H4; my imagination it is: my gorge
rises at it. Here hung those lips that&H61; I have kissed I know not howe
oft, where be your gibes now? your gambols, your songs, your flashes of merriment, that&H61; were wont to&H9; set the table
on&H4; a roar, not one
now to&H9; mock your own grinning, quite chap fallen. Now get you
to&H4; my Lady's table, and tell her&H6;, let her&H6; paint an inch thick, to&H4; this favour she must come, make her&H6; laugh at that&H62;.
Prithee Horatio tell me one thing.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: What is that&H62; my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Dost thou think Alexander looked a this fashion in&H4; the earth?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Even so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: And smelt so&H52; pah.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Even so&H52; my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
To&H4; what base uses we&Htp; may return Horatio? Why may not
imagination trace the noble dust of Alexander, till he find it stopping
a bunghole?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: It were to&H9; consider too curiously to&H9; consider so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
No&H7; faith, not a jot, but to&H9; follow him thither with modesty
enough, and likelihood to&H9; lead it. Alexander dyed, Alexander was
buried, Alexander returneth to&H4; dust, the dust is earth, of earth we&Htp;
make Loam, and why of that&H62; Loam whereto he was converted, might
they not stop a Beer-barrel?
sp.l: Imperious Caesar dead, and turned to&H4; Clay,
Might stop a hole, to&H9; keep the wind away.
O that&H3; that&H62; earth which&H61; kept the world in&H4; awe,
Should patch a wall to&H9; expel the water's flaw.
But soft, but soft awhile, here comes the King,

stage.l: Enter K. Q. Laertes and the corse.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: The Queen, the Courtiers, who&H62; is this they follow?
And with such maimed rites? this doth betoken,
The corse they follow, did with desperate hand
Foredo it own life, it was of some estate,
Couch we&Htp; a while and mark.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: What Ceremony else?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: That&H62; is Laertes a very noble youth, mark.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: What Ceremony else?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Her&H2; obsequies have been as far enlarged
As we&Htp; have warranty, her&H2; death was doubtful,
And but that&H3; great command ore-sways the order,
She should in&H4; ground unsanctified been lodged
Till the last trumpet: for&H3; charitable prayers,
Flints and pebbles should be thrown on&H4; her&H6;:
Yet here she is allowed her&H2; virgin Crants,
Her&H2; maiden strewments, and the bringing home
Of bell and burial.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Must there no&H2; more be done?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: No&H2; more be done.
We&Htp; should profane the service of the dead,
To&H9; sing a Requiem and such rest to&H4; her&H6;
As to&H4; peace-parted souls.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Lay her&H6; in&H4; the earth,
And from her&H2; fair and unpolluted flesh
May Violets spring: I tell thee churlish Priest,
A ministering Angel shall my sister be
When thou liest howling.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What, the fair Ophelia.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Sweets to&H4; the sweet, farewell,
I hoped thou shouldst have been my Hamlets wife,
I thought thy bride-bed to&H9; have decked sweet maid,
And not have strewed thy grave.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: O treble woe
Fall ten times double on&H4; that&H62; cursed head,
Whose wicked deed thy most ingenious sense
Deprived thee of, hold off the earth a while,
Till I have caught her&H6; once more in&H4; mine arms;
Now pile your dust upon&H4; the quick and dead,
Till of this flat a mountain you have made
To&H9; overtop old Pelion, or the skyish head
Of blue Olympus.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What is he whose grief
Bears such an emphasis, whose phrase of sorrow
Conjures the wandering stars, and makes them stand
Like&H4; wonder wounded hearers: this is I
Hamlet the Dane.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: The devil take thy soul.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Thou prayest not well, I prithee take thy fingers from my throat,
For&H3; though I am not spleenative rash,
Yet have I in&H4; me something dangerous,
Which&H61; let thy wisdom fear; hold off thy hand,

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Pluck them asunder.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Hamlet, Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Hor. Claud. Quee. Doct.
sp.l: Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Good my Lord be quiet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why, I will&H1; fight with him upon&H4; this theme
Until my eye-lids will&H1; no&H2; longer wag.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: O my son, what theme?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I loved Ophelia, forty thousand brothers
Could not with all their quantity of love
Make up&H5; my sum. What wilt thou do for&H4; her&H6;.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: O he is mad Laertes.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: For&H4; love of God forbear him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: 'swounds show me what thou would do:
Wilt weep, wilt fight, wilt fast, wilt tear thyself,
Wilt drink up&H5; Esill, eat a Crocodile?
I will&H1; do it, dost come here to&H9; whine?
To&H9; out-face me with leaping in&H4; her&H2; grave,
Be buried quick with her&H6;, and so&H52; will&H1; I.
And if thou prate of mountains, let them throw
Millions of Acres on&H4; us&Htp;, till our&Htp; ground
Singeing his pate against the burning Zone
Make Ossa like&H4; a wart, nay if thou wilt mouth,
I will&H1; rant as well as thou.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: This is mere madness,
And this a while the fit will&H1; work on&H4; him,
Anon as patient as the female Dove
When that&H3; her&H2; golden cuplets are disclosed
His silence will&H1; sit drooping.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Hear you sir,
What is the reason that&H3; you use me thus?
I loved you ever, but it is no&H2; matter,
Let Hercules himself do what he may
The Cat will&H1; mew, and Dog will&H1; have his day.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I pray thee good Horatio wait upon&H4; him.
Strengthen your patience in&H4; our&Htp; last night's speech,
We&Hrp; will&H1; put the matter to&H4; the present push:
Good Gertrard set some watch over your son,
This grave shall have a living monument,
An hour of quiet thereby shall we&Hrp; see
Tell then in&H4; patience our&Hrp; proceeding be.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: So&H51; much for&H4; this sir, now shall you see the other,
You do remember all the circumstance.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Remember it my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Sir in&H4; my heart there was a kind of fighting
That&H61; would not let me sleep, methought I lay
Worse than the mutinies in&H4; the bilbo, rashly,
And praised be rashness for&H4; it: let us&Htp;, know,
Our&Htp; indiscretion sometime serves us&Htp;, well
When our&Htp; deep plots do fall, and that&H62; should learn us&Htp;,
There is a divinity that&H61; shapes our&Htp; ends,
Rough hew them how we&Htp; will&H1;.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: That&H62; is most certain.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Up&H5; from my Cabin,
My sea-gown scarfed about me in&H4; the dark
Groped I to&H9; find out them, had my desire,
Fingered their packet, and in&H4; fine with-drew
To&H4; mine own room again, making so&H51; bold
My fears forgetting manners to&H9; unfold
Their grand commission; where I found Horatio
A royal knavery, an exact command
Larded with many several sorts of reasons,
Importing Denmarkes health, and Englands too,
With ho such bugs and goblins in&H4; my life,
That&H3; on&H4; the supervise no&H2; leisure bated,
No&H7; not to&H9; stay the grinding of the Axe,
My head should be struck off.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Here is the commission, read it at more leisure,
But wilt thou hear now how I did proceed.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Being thus benetted round with villains,
Or I could make a prologue to&H4; my brains,
They had begun the play, I sat me down,
Devised a new commission, wrote it fair,
I once did hold it as our&Htp; statists do,
A baseness to&H9; write fair, and laboured much
How to&H9; forget that&H62; learning, but sir now
It did me yeoman's service, wilt thou know
The effect of what I wrote?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Aye good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: An earnest conjuration from the King,
As England was his faithful tributary,
As love between them like&H2; the palm might flourish,
As peace should still her&H2; wheaten garland wear
And stand a Comma tween their amities,
And many such like&H2;, as sir of great charge,
That&H3; on&H4; the view, and knowing of these contents,
Without debatement further more or less,
He should those bearers put to&H4; sudden death,
Not shriving time allowed.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: How was this sealed?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why even in&H4; that&H62; was heaven ordinant,
I had my father's signet in&H4; my purse
Which&H61; was the model of that&H62; Danish seal,
Folded the writ up&H5; in&H4; the form of the other,
Subscribe it, gave it the impression, placed it safely,
The changeling never known: now the next day
Was our&Htp; Sea fight, and what to&H4; this was sequent
Thou knowest already.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: So&H3; Guyldensterne and Rosencraus go to&H4; it.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: They are not near my conscience, their defeat
Does by&H4; their own insinuation grow,
It is dangerous when the baser nature comes
Between the pass and fell incensed points
Of mighty opposites.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Why what a King is this!

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Does it not think thee stand me now upon&H5;?
He that&H61; hath killed my King, and whored my mother,
Popped in&H5; between the election and my hopes,
Thrown out his Angle for&H4; my proper life,
And with such cozenage, is it not perfect conscience?

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.l: Your Lordship is right welcome back to&H4; Denmarke.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I humble thank you sir.
Dost know this water fly?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: No&H7; my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Thy state is the more gracious, for&H3; it is a vice to&H9; know him,
He hath much land and fertile: let a beast be Lord of beasts, and his
crib shall stand at the King's mess, it is a chough, but as I say, spacious in&H4; the possession of dirt.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p:
Sweet Lord, if your Lordship were at leisure, I should
impart a thing to&H4; you from his Majesty.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I will&H1; receive it sir with all dilligence of spirit, your bonnet
to&H4; his right use, it is for&H4; the head.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p: I thank your Lordship, it is very hot.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: No&H7; believe me, it is very cold, the wind is Northerly.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p: It is indifferent cold my Lord indeed.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: But yet methinks it is very sully and hot, or my complexion.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p:
Exceedingly my Lord, it is very sultry, as it were I cannot tell how: my Lord his Majesty bad me signify to&H4; you, that&H3; he
has laid a great wager on&H4; your head, sir this is the matter.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I beseech you remember.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p:
Nay good my Lord for&H4; my ease in&H4; good faith, sir here is newly
come to&H4; Court Laertes, believe me an absolute gentlemen, full of most
excellent differences, of very soft society, and great showing : indeed to&H9; speak sellingly of him, he is the card or calendar of gentry: for&H3; you shall find in&H4; him the
continent of what part a Gentleman would see.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Sir, his definement suffers no&H2; perdition in&H4; you, though I
know to&H9; divide him inventorially, would dizzy the arithmetic of
memory, and yet but raw neither, in&H4; respect of his quick sail, but
in&H4; the verity of extolment, I take him to&H9; be a soul of great article,
and his infusion of such dearth and rareness, as to&H9; make true diction
of him, his semblable is his mirror, and who&H62; else would trace him, his
umbrage, nothing more.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p: Your Lordship speaks most infallibly of him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
The concernancy sir, why do we&Htp; wrap the gentleman in&H4;
our&Htp; more rawer breath?

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Is it not possible to&H9; understand in&H4; another tongue, you will&H1;
do it sir really.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What imports the nomination of this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p: Of Laertes.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: His purse is empty already, all his golden words are spent.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Of him sir.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p: I know you are not ignorant.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I would you did sir, yet in&H4; faith if you did, it would not
much approve me, well sir.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p: You are not ignorant of what excellence Laertes is.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I dare not confess that&H62;, lest I should compare with
him in&H4; excellence, but to&H9; know a man well, were to&H9; know himself.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p:
I mean sir for&H4; this weapon, but in&H4; the imputation laid on&H4;
him, by&H4; them in&H4; his meed, he is unblowed.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What is his weapon?

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p: Rapier and Dagger.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: That&H62; is two of his weapons, but well.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p:
The King sir hath wagered with him six Barbary horses,
against the which&H61; he has impawned as I take it six French Rapiers
and Poniards, with their assigns, as girdle, hanger and so&H3;. Three
of the carriages in&H4; faith, are very dear to&H4; fancy, very revenge to&H4;
the hilts, most delicate carriages, and of very liberal conceit.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What call you the carriages?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p:
I knew you must be edified by&H4; the margent ere you had
done.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p: The carriage sir are the hangers.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
The phrase would be more germane to&H4; the matter if we&Htp;
could carry a cannon by&H4; our&Htp; sides, I would it be might hangers till
then, but on&H5;, six Barbry horses against six French swords their assigns, and three liberal conceited carriages, that&H62; is the French
bet against the Danish, why is this all you call it?

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p:
The King sir, hath laid sir, that&H3; in&H4; a dozen passes between
yourself and him, he shall not exceed you three hits, he hath
laid on&H4; twelve for&H4; nine, and it would come to&H4; immediate trial, if
your Lordship would vouchsafe the answer.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: How if I answer no&H7;?

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p: I mean my Lord the opposition of your person in&H4; trial.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Sir I will&H1; walk here in&H4; the hall, if it please his Majesty, it
is the breathing time of day with me, let the foils be brought, the
Gentleman willing, and the King hold his purpose; I will&H1; win
for&H4; him if I can, if not, I will&H1; gain nothing but my shame, and
the odd hits.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p: Shall I deliver you so&H52;?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: To&H4; this effect sir, after what flourish your nature will&H1;.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p: I commend my duty to&H4; your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Yours does well to&H9; commend it himself, there are no&H2;
tongues else for&H4; his turn.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: This Lapwing runs away with the shell on&H4; his head.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
He did so&H52; sir with his dug before he sucked it, thus has he and
many more of the same breed that&H61; I know the drossy age dotes on&H5;,
only got the tune of the time, and out of an habit of encounter, a
kind of histy collection, which&H61; carries them through and through
the most profane and trennowed opinions, and do but blow
them to&H4; their trial, the bubbles are out.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p:
My Lord, his Majesty commended him to&H4; you by&H4; young
Ostricke, who&H61; brings back to&H4; him that&H3; you attend him in&H4; the hall,
he sends to&H9; know if your pleasure hold to&H9; play with Laertes, or that&H3;
you will&H1; take longer time?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I am constant to&H4; my purposes, they follow the King's pleasure, if his fitness speaks, mine is ready: now or whensoever, provided I be so&H51;
able as now.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: The King, and Queen, and all are coming down.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: In&H4; happy time.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p:
The Queen desires you to&H9; use some gentle entertainment
to&H4; Laertes, before you fall to&H9; play.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: She well instructs me.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: You will&H1; lose my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I do not think so&H52;, since he went into France, I have been
in&H4; continual practise, I shall win at the odds; thou wouldst not
think how ill all is here about my heart, but it is no&H2; matter.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Nay good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
It is but foolery, but it is such a kind of gain-giving, as
would perhaps trouble a woman.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p:
If your mind dislike anything, obey it. I will&H1; forestall their
repair hither, and say you are not fit.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Not a whit, we&Htp; defy augury, there is special providence, in&H4;
the fall of a Sparrow, if it be, it is not to&H9; come, if it be not to&H9; come,
it will&H1; be now, if it be not now, yet it well come, the readiness is all,
since no&H2; man of aught he leaves, knows what is it to&H9; leave betimes,
let be.

stage.l: A table prepard, Trumpets, Drums and officers with Cushions,
King, Queene, and all the state, Foiles, daggers,

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Come Hamlet, come and take this hand from me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Give me your pardon sir, I have done you wrong,
But pardon it as you are a gentleman, this presence knows,
And you must needs have heard, how I am punished
With a sore distraction, what I have done
That&H61; might your nature, honour, and exception
Roughly awake, I hear proclaim was madness,
Wast Hamlet wronged Laertes? never Hamlet.
If Hamlet from himself be taken away,
And when he is not himself, does wrong Laertes,
Then Hamlet does it not, Hamlet denies it,
Who&H62; does it then? his madness. If it be so&H52;,
Hamlet is of the faction that&H61; is wronged,
His madness is poor Hamlets enemy,
Let my disclaiming from a purposed evil,
Free me so&H51; far in&H4; your most generous thoughts
That&H3; I have shot my arrow over the house
And hurt my brother.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I am satisfied in&H4; nature,
Whose motive in&H4; this case should stir me most
To&H4; my revenge, but in&H4; my terms of honour
I stand aloof, and will&H1; no&H2; reconcilement,
Till by&H4; some elder Masters of known honour
I have a voice and president of peace
To&H4; my name ungored: but all that&H62; time
I do receive your offered love, like&H4; love,
And will&H1; not wrong it.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I embrace it freely, and will&H1; this brother's wager
frankly play.
Give us&Htp;, the foils.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Come, one for&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I will&H1; be your foil Laertes, in&H4; mine ignorance
Your skill shall like&H4; a star in&H4; the darkest night
Stick fiery off indeed.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: You mock me sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No&H7; by&H4; this hand.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Give them the foils young Ostricke, cousin Hamlet,
You know the wager.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Very well my Lord.
Your grace has laid the odds on&H4; the weaker side.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I do not fear it, I have seen you both,
But since he is better, we&Hrp; have therefore odds.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: This is too heavy: let me see another.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: This likes me well, these foils have all a length.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.l: Aye my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Set me the stoups of wine upon&H4; that&H62; table,
If Hamlet give the first or second hit,
Or quit in&H4; answer of the third exchange,
Let all the battlements their ordnance fire.
The King shall drink to&H4; Hamlets better breath,
And in&H4; the cup an Onyx shall he throw,
Richer than that&H62; which&H61; four successive Kings
In&H4; Denmarkes Crown have worn: give me the cups,
And let the kettle to&H4; the trumpet speak,
The trumpet to&H4; the Cannoneer without,
The Cannons to&H4; the heavens, the heaven to&H4; earth,
Now the King drinks to&H4; Hamlet, come begin.
And you the Judges bear a wary eye.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Come on&H5; sir.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Come my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: One.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: No&H7;.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Judgment.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.p: A hit, a very palpable hit.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.p: Well, again.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Stay, give me drink, Hamlet this pearl is thine.
Here is to&H4; thy health: give him the cup.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I will&H1; play this bout first, set it by&H5; a while
Come, another hit.
What say you?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I do confess it.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Our&Hrp; son shall win.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: He is fat and scant of breath.
Here Hamlet take my napkin rub thy brows,
The Queen carouses to&H4; thy fortune Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Good Madam.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Gertrard do not drink.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: I will&H1; my Lord, I pray you pardon me.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: It is the poisoned cup, it is too late.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I dare not drink yet Madam, by&H5; and by&H5;.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Come, let me wipe thy face.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: My Lord, I will&H1; hit him now.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I do not think it.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: And yet it is almost against my conscience.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Come for&H4; the third Laertes, you do but dally.
I pray you pass with your best violence
I am sure you make a wanton of me.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Say you so&H52;, come on&H5;.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.l: Nothing neither way.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Have at you now.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Part them, they are incensed.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay come again.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.l: Look to&H4; the Queen there howe.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: They bleed on&H4; both sides, how is it my Lord?

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.l: How is it Laertes?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Why as a woodcock to&H4; mine own springe Ostrick,
I am justly killed with mine own treachery.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How does the Queen?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: She sounds to&H9; see them bleed.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: No&H7;, no&H7;, the drink, the drink, o my dear Hamlet,
The drink the drink, I am poisoned.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O villainy, how let the door be locked,
Treachery, seek it out.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: It is here Hamlet, thou art slain,
No&H2; medicine in&H4; the world can do thee good,
In&H4; thee there is not half an hour's life,
The treacherous instrument is in&H4; my hand
Unbated and envenomed, the foul practise
Hath turned itself on&H4; me, lo here I lie
Never to&H9; rise again, thy mother is poisoned,
I can no&H2; more, the King, the King is to&H4; blame.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: The point envenomed too, then venom to&H4; thy work.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: O yet defend me friends, I am but hurt.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Hear thou incestuous damned Dane,
Drink of this potion, is the Onyx here?
Follow my mother.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: He is justly served, it is a poison tempered by&H4; himself,
Exchange forgiveness with me noble Hamlet,
Mine and my father's death come not upon&H4; thee,
Nor thine on&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Heaven make thee free of it, I follow thee;
I am dead Horatio, wretched Queen adieu.
You that&H61; look pale, and tremble at this chance,
That&H61; are but mutes, or audience to&H4; this act,
Had I but time, as this fell sergeant Death
Is strict in&H4; his arrest, o I could tell you,
But let it be; Horatio I am dead,
Thou livest, report me and my cause aright
To&H4; the unsatisfied.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Never believe it;
I am more an antic Roman than a Dane,
Here is yet some liquor left.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: As thou art a man
Give me the cup, let go, by&H4; heaven I will&H1; have it,
O god Horatio, what a wounded name
Things standing thus unknown, shall I leave behind me?
If thou didst ever hold me in&H4; thy heart,
Absent thee from felicity a while,
And in&H4; this harsh world draw thy breath in&H4; pain
To&H9; tell my story: what warlike noise is this?

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.l: Young Fortenbrasse with conquest come from Poland,
To&H4; the ambassadors of England gives this warlike volley.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O I die Horatio,
The potent poison quite overcrows my spirit,
I cannot live to&H9; hear the news from England,
But I do prophesy the election lights
On&H4; Fortinbrasse, he has my dying voice,
So&H52; tell him, with the occurrents more and less
Which&H61; have solicited, the rest is silence.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Now cracks a noble heart, good night sweet Prince,
And flights of Angels sing thee to&H4; thy rest.
Why does the drum come hither?

sp.speaker: Fortin.
sp.l: Where is this sight?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: What is it you would see?
If aught of woe, or wonder, cease your search.

sp.speaker: Fortin.
sp.l: This quarry cries on&H4; havoc, o proud death
What feast is toward in&H4; thine eternal cell,
That&H3; thou so&H51; many Princes at a shot
So&H51; bloodily hast struck?

sp.speaker: Embas.
sp.l: The sight is dismal
And our&Htp; affairs from England come too late,
The ears are senseless that&H61; should give us&Htp;, hearing,
To&H9; tell him his commandment is fulfilled,
That&H3; Rosencraus and Guyldensterne are dead,
Where should we&Htp; have our&Htp; thanks?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Not from his mouth
Had it the ability of life to&H9; thank you;
He never gave commandment for&H4; their death;
But since so&H51; jump upon&H4; this bloody question
You from the Pollack wars, and you from England
Are here arrived, give order that&H3; these bodies
High on&H4; a stage be placed to&H4; the view,
And let me speak, to&H4; yet unknowing world
How these things came about; so&H52; shall you hear
Of carnal, bloody and unnatural acts,
Of accidental judgments, casual slaughters,
Of deaths put on&H5; by&H4; cunning, and for&H4; no&H2; cause
And in&H4; this upshot, purposes mistook,
Fallen on&H4; the inventors' heads: all this can I
Truly deliver.

sp.speaker: Fortin.
sp.l: Let us&Htp;, haste to&H9; hear it,
And call the noblest to&H4; the audience,
For&H4; me, with sorrow I embrace my fortune,
I have some rights, of memory in&H4; this kingdom,
Which&H61; now to&H9; claim my vantage doth invite me.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Of that&H62; I shall have also cause to&H9; speak,
And from his mouth, whose voice will&H1; draw no&H2; more,
But let this same be presently performed
Even while men's minds are wild, lest more mischance
On&H4; plots and errors happen.

sp.speaker: Fortin.
sp.l: Let four Captains
Bear Hamlet like&H4; a soldier to&H4; the stage,
For&H3; he was likely, had he been put on&H5;,
To&H9; have proved most royal; and for&H4; his passage,
The soldiers' music and the right of war
Speak loudly for&H4; him:
Take up&H5; the bodies, such a sight as this,
Becomes the field, but here shows much amiss.
Go bid the soldiers shoot.
